SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RUDDOCK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In closing, I would like to take the opportunity of dealing with some matters that were raised in the Main Committee in relation to the Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1997 . First, may I thank the honourable member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), the opposition shadow minister; the member for Petrie (Ms Gambaro) and the member for Deakin (Mr Barresi) from this side of the House; and the member for Fraser (Mr Dargavel), the member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson), the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) and the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) for their contributions. This is a serious matter. It is one which I hope the opposition shadow minister will carefully listen to what I have to say and that he and his colleagues may reconsider their position on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Latham interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that a sexist comment addressed to me?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Latham interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but I understand the offence that was taken was the suggestion that it might be sexist in some way. The word is not.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. It goes to a question of relevance. I thought we were dealing with migration, not a question of sexist remarks or who dresses in drag.
—I thank the honourable member for Batman, and I would also encourage his colleague sitting on his left to refrain from interjecting.

—I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I thank the honourable member for Batman for his helpful point of order. I will take the opportunity of dealing with a number of matters that the honourable member for Batman raised. The member for Batman referred to an article in the Weekend Australian dealing with criminal elements entering Australia. I have carefully read the article that I believe he was referring to, which said:

SPEECH.PARA: Police have been warned of a flood of illegal Asian immigrants entering Australia through corrupt consulate officials, sham English‐language courses and organised crime syndicates.

What I find interesting is the linkage that he made in view of those observations with migration agents. There is nothing I can see in the article that makes any reference to linking migration agents with the entry of criminals into Australia. Obviously, if the member has any information of that sort, he should provide it to us so that it can be investigated. I regard the allegations that the honourable member made very seriously because I do place a great deal of emphasis on character issues. In this matter of the importance of character issues, I would judge very much the opposition by the response that they will make in several weeks to the bill that I have just introduced into the House today.

The further comment that was made, and I think it was picked up by other members who spoke, was the reference to the Joint Standing Committee on Migration report entitled Protecting the vulnerable? I was a party to that committee report, and I know what happened in relation to the deliberations on it. I know that the report was not one that had been responded to by the former government—notwithstanding that it was a committee report that they had had in their hands for some 12 months before the last election. I think that says something of the former government's aspirations to dealing with a number of the matters that the committee raised, which I have—

TALK.START.PARA: —We thought we were going to be re-elected.
—You did not expect to be re-elected?
—I said, `We thought we were going to be re-elected.'
—You did not expect you were going to be re-elected.
—Order! The minister will ignore the chatter across the table.
—Let me just say that the existing scheme has had mixed results. That was the judgment of the committee. If you read page 61 of the report, you will find this quote:

BREAK.PARA: To date, the Migration Agents Registration Scheme has achieved mixed results. Critics of the Scheme suggested that it has had little if any impact on the standard and conduct of persons providing immigration advice. They cited continuing problems with poor advice and unscrupulous practice as evidence of the Scheme's failure to make any discernible difference.
The committee went on to say:
Statistics obtained by the Committee support a finding that the achievements of the Scheme relevant to its objectives have been chequered.

Moving to a statutory self-regulation scheme does not go against the recommendations of that committee. While the committee considered that self-regulation was not viable at the time of the report, it did not rule out that it may be viable in the future. I think that is the important point to note: this scheme which we are implementing will ensure that a self-regulatory scheme will be viable. It will ensure, because it is statutory, that all migration agents, in order to be able to practise, will be members of the institute.

The government's new scheme reflects also a number of other recommendations from the report. I make the point that everyone who is to give immigration advice, other than those who have had the same form of statutory exemption in the past, has to be registered. There will be a code of conduct regulating agents behaviour. There will be additional measures to improve competency. I have to say that, in my judgment, peer pressure from the sorts of people who were sensible enough to belong to an institute which was concerned about standards is going to be far stronger in its coercion to improve standards than the regulatory scheme has proved to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bit like the Law Society.

—I suspect that one of the reasons that the legal profession have been concerned about these matters, and continue to be concerned about these matters, arises from an expectation that the standards may well be pressed very strongly by the institute. Certainly my dealings with the people who have been at a senior level of that organisation give me confidence in the belief that the system can work.

BREAK.PARA: There were allegations made by members who spoke about reduction in funding to advice bodies. The honourable member for Batman was at a public forum in Melbourne where I spoke, where this issue had been raised. He heard what I had to say then, and I will repeat it now. I said:

The grant funding previously provided to community advice bodies under the former immigration advisory services scheme has been fully incorporated into the new immigration advice and application assistance scheme. The two previous schemes have been merged into one, and the new scheme will provide the full range of services that were previously provided. These services include: immigration advice and application assistance to asylum seekers and other disadvantaged people in the community; application assistance for asylum seekers in detention; and training for voluntary sector migration agents. These services have been put out to tender throughout Australia and the overall level of funding has been increased by two per cent.

My expectation is, and it is being realised, that we will get better value for money through the tender process. In that sense, there has been no overall reduction at all in the level of funding available for voluntary service delivery.

I have made some further inquiries because it is important to be able to clarify for the House some of the changes that occurred as a result of the review that was undertaken. The planned allocation of resources between the states for immigration advice and assistance services has been altered. That reflects significantly increased numbers of residence applications in New South Wales. Between 43 and 45 per cent of all new arrivals have been going to New South Wales for a number of years now and service delivery has not reflected that circumstance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pollution; urban sprawl.

—The member mentions those factors, but the point I am making is that I am trying to get a better dispersal of the outcome. In relation to the delivery of services, we had a situation in 1996-97 where 40 per cent of the funding went to Victoria and 30 per cent of the funding went to New South Wales. That reflected the historical distribution of applications and there has been some change, which has prompted some of the organisations that have seen that change to complain. The planned allocations for 1997-98 will see 26 per cent of the funding going to Victoria and 44 per cent of the funding going to New South Wales.

BREAK.PARA: I want to make some comments on the second reading amendment moved by the opposition. In relation to the charge that the bill will open the way for unscrupulous agents to exploit the vulnerable, let me make the point that this bill retains all of the important consumer protection elements in the existing scheme. The new scheme improves the existing protection elements. Agents will be required to register and meet entry standards in order to practise. Agents will be subject to an expanded code of conduct and will be subject to sanctions if they breach that code.

Agents will have to meet new competency and professional development requirements in order to obtain further periods of registration. Previously re‐registration was automatic and there was no testing of skills. That is a significant change and a beneficial change. Agents who fail to meet these requirements will be refused registration and will not be eligible for further registration for another 12 months. Any further move to self‐regulation depends on a review of these arrangements that will be undertaken before March 2000.

There have been some questions raised in the second paragraph of the opposition's second reading amendment in relation to voluntary agents not having to pay registration fees. Currently there are about 450 non-fee charging agents who work in the voluntary sector and do not pay a registration fee. They did not have to meet the same standards as fee charging agents. You cannot tolerate a two-tier system where the most vulnerable, about whom you were speaking, receive a lower standard of service. That was what was happening under the existing scheme. If you do not have to meet the same educational qualifications and prove them—
Mr Martin Ferguson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You make that observation. All I am saying is that the standards under the legislation were not the same and were not required to be the same. That is the fact. You can make these allegations, but that was the legal regime that you had in place. All agents will be required to be registered and will be charged a fee. All agents will be required to meet the same knowledge test. The government is providing training to assist voluntary sector agents to meet the full knowledge test and registration through the immigration advice and assistance scheme.

BREAK.PARA: The only other point I would make is that there will still be a disparity in the fees. The voluntary agents will pay a fee of $450 compared with full registration fees of around $1,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who authorised the negotiation of the fees?
—I was involved in the settlement of those matters and they had to be dealt with by me.
—What are the fees?

—I just told you what they will be. In relation to the claim in the third paragraph of the opposition's second reading amendment that consumer rights will be marginalised and there will be no overall monitoring authority, let me make the point that the overall monitoring authority is and remains under this legislation the government. The bill gives me as the minister the power to register and sanction migration agents. It allows me to appoint an agent to undertake that work, and I intend to appoint the Migration Institute of Australia as the migration agents registration authority.

BREAK.PARA: The appointment will be supported by a formal agreement between that organisation and me on how these powers are to be exercised. Its performance will be closely monitored. The appointment is able to be revoked by me if the powers are not being exercised in the interests of consumers. The act will continue to provide that decisions made about registration agents may be reviewed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. So the opposition needs to recognise that this is a statutory self-regulatory scheme; it does not deregulate the industry.

The further point I would make relates to the opposition's claim about the reduction in time for lodging of objections to proposed registration. I could go on for some time, but let me say at the moment the notification about which there is a longer time is provided in the government Gazette. I do not know how many people actually read the government Gazette to look for notifications as to who is going to be a registered migration agent, but I suspect very few consumers ever read the government Gazette. The government intends that agents will have to publish their intention in major daily newspapers to ensure the widest possible coverage.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the front page?
—Come on, be sensible.
—Or buried in the classifieds?

—In major daily newspapers. This needs to be compared with the current situation where it is done in the government Gazette . In relation to seeking the continuation of existing arrangements in the opposition's second reading amendment, let me make it clear that, if this bill is opposed, it is not a question of going back to the existing scheme. Under the sunset clause, which you have included in the legislation and which we have extended to enable this bill to be introduced, and without this bill, there will be no registration scheme. The sunset clause will come into effect next March and we will have a totally unregulated industry.

BREAK.PARA: If you believe that there is a need for improvements, support the bill. The bill enables you to give effect to a much more substantial and effective scheme than was left in place by your government and it is one that will continue to exist. If there is no scheme, I can tell you who will be responsible and who will be seen to be responsible. It will be those who oppose the willingness to improve the system through a self-regulatory model.

Let me deal with the schizophrenia of the Labor Party as a final matter. The Labor Party is schizophrenic on this issue. They are railing about the need to deal with `shonks and crooks in the industry'—they were the words used in the committee stage. Yet when it comes to supporting sensible measures to enable us to take away some of the opportunities for people to exploit our law, they are quite prepared to oppose these measures in the parliament. It was only a week or so ago that we saw the Labor Party oppose the seeking of the opportunity to limit the situations in which non bona fide applicants are able to exploit judicial review.

We have introduced legislation which contains a privative clause, which is very important in enabling us to deal with those matters. And when it is a question of dealing with shonks and crooks and denying them the opportunity of exploiting the system, the opposition is quite prepared—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is drawing a long bow.

—It is not a long bow. It is direct and it applies directly to the very people you are saying are exploiting the vulnerable. We want to take away that opportunity. If you want to give evidence of your bona fides in these matters, support that legislation.

BREAK.PARA: Earlier today, as I said, I introduced further legislation to strengthen the character provisions. I am going to arrange a briefing for the honourable member because I want him to be aware of the nature of these provisions and how they are intended to operate. How you respond to that legislation will be a further test of your bona fides in these matters. Here is an opportunity for you to reconsider your position, to withdraw your amendment and to support sensible legislation which improves registration of migration agents and effectively ensures the protection of some of those whom you have identified, and I acknowledge, can be very vulnerable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendment be agreed to.

I am asking the House to agree to the Native Title Amendment (Tribunal Appointments) Bill 1997 as amended by the Senate due to the pressing need to have the amendments contained in the bill passed in the legislation.

BREAK.PARA: The bill as amended includes a provision altering the qualifications for the appointment of the registrar of the National Native Title Tribunal. The amendments remove the requirement that the registrar be admitted to legal practice for five years and replace it with a requirement that a person may not be appointed as registrar unless the person is legally qualified and has had substantial experience in relation to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander societies or the law or administration or any other class of activity considered relevant to the duties of the registrar.

As the registrar will no longer have any role in deciding whether or not applications should be accepted, it is appropriate that the qualifications for appointment be changed. The proposed amendment will ensure that a more diverse field of suitably qualified candidates may be considered for the position of registrar of the tribunal. The registrar has agreed to stay on until the end of the year to allow a suitable replacement to be appointed. Therefore, as it is imperative that the bill is passed to allow a replacement appointment to be made before the end of the year, the government is accepting the bill as amended.

The Senate did not agree to a proposed amendment to the qualifications of presidential members. Currently, a presidential member has to be a Federal Court judge or a former judge of the High Court, Federal Court or state or territory Supreme Court in order to be eligible for selection. This not only severely restricts the pool from which suitable candidates can be drawn, it also means that otherwise highly qualified people, especially those experienced in the rapidly developing area of native title law, are excluded from consideration.

The proposed amendment sought to include a further class of persons who could be appointed as a presidential member, that is, a person who has been admitted to legal practice for at least five years. The Senate did not agree to this amendment. The constitution requires that judicial functions involving the determination of people's legal rights are exercised by the courts and not tribunals or commissions. Restricting presidential appoint ments to the tribunal to Superior Court judges only means that judges are taken away from where they are most needed by the public—determining people's rights under law—and placed in a tribunal to undertake functions that differ from their judicial role.

This amendment is essential to the changed role of the tribunal as a result of the Brandy decision. Accordingly, the government is committed to bringing back to parliament in the near future this necessary alteration to the selection requirement for the appointment of presidential members for the National Native Title Tribunal. I commend the amendment to the House.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to pay tribute to a great Australian who passed away yesterday. Dr H.C. `Nugget' Coombs has been described as a planner of dreams, an inexhaustible resource, a rebel, and the most influential public servant in Australian history. An adviser to seven prime ministers, Nugget Coombs earned the respect of men as divergent in their world views as Bob Menzies and Gough Whitlam.

SPEECH.PARA: Nugget Coombs was a dedicated and passionate man who shared his wisdom without fear or favour. Nugget Coombs was an accomplished, hands-on economist who believed the economy should serve the people—and not the reverse.

As shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs it is fitting that I say a few words about Nugget Coombs' contribution to the advancement of indigenous Australians. Nugget Coombs was appointed to chair the Council for Aboriginal Affairs in 1968. From that moment, his life and work became more and more involved in the struggle to help indigenous Australians take control of their lives and make their own way in the nation.

So respected was he by indigenous Australians that he was the only whitefella invited to attend the crucial Eva Valley meeting in 1993, where an indigenous position on proposed native title legislation was hammered out. Nugget was a fearless advocate of what he called `Aboriginal autonomy'. He argued strongly that indigenous people should be empowered to take control of their own lives on their own terms. He was convinced that native title rights are essential to achieving that goal.

Nugget Coombs was a hardworking man. Even in the last few years before he suffered a stroke three years ago, he was still working eight‐, 10‐ and 12‐hour days—researching, writing and visiting remote Aboriginal communities, participating in the affairs of the Australian National University, or sharing his wisdom with the many politicians, businessmen, indigenous people and others who came to him for advice.

He has published countless articles and essays on issues related to indigenous affairs and was recognised as one of the leading authorities in a wide range of subject areas. The books he published include: Other People's Money; The Fragile Pattern; Trial Balance—his autobiography; A Certain Heritage—of which he was co-author; and The Return of Scarcity; as well as a collection of his works published in 1994 entitled Aboriginal Autonomy.

Nugget died on the same day the government's flawed native title legislation went through this House. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) should read another of Nugget's works. It's called Kulinma: Listening to Aboriginal Australians. But I want to read from the preface to Aboriginal Autonomy. In 1994 Nugget wrote:

Greed, contempt for future generations and willingness to exploit racial antagonism in order to resist change have become, with honourable but few exceptions, the mark of the policies of those who desire to control the world's resources.
Mick Dodson, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner, said of Nugget Coombs:
That old man must be respected. He is the white fellas most senior elder.

I think the last word should go to Nugget himself. Asked by Michael Gordon of the Australian newspaper how he would like to be remembered, Nugget Coombs said simply, `He was a good bloke.' In closing, I want to pay tribute to our most senior elder, Nugget Coombs: a good bloke whose contribution to Australian society cannot be overestimated; a public servant who did serve the public and the community in an exceptional manner. We salute you, Nugget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Draper, Trish, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —May I also extend my condolences to the family of Nugget Coombs. Tonight I was going to speak about two issues in this adjournment debate, firstly, the JPET program which I launched last Friday in my electorate of Makin and which is to be administered by the Salvation Army Ingle Farm Community Service and, secondly, a wonderful school community within my electorate of Makin.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Rod Tyney, the Principal of Para Hills Primary School, invited me to join the school to participate in their family fun day on Sunday, 26 October. The reason I wanted to speak on these events was to acknowledge the wonderful work accomplished by the volunteers in the various communities of my electorate of Makin. However, there is one particular special volunteer whom I would like to pay tribute to this evening.

My special tribute is for Mr Brian Houlson, a member of the Newland Central Branch within the Makin Federal Electoral Committee. Brian Houlson passed away last night and it was late this morning that I received this very sad and tragic news. The news has been particularly devastating as Brian was still of a young age and a very active and enthusiastic supporter of all of our Liberal activities, within both the electorates of Newland and Makin.

He was a devoted member along with his wife, Mrs Christine Houlson, and family members who survive him, especially supporting the member for Newland, the Hon. Dorothy Kotz, Minister for the Environment. My heart goes out to Christine Houlson. I am sure I speak for all members of our FEC and Newland SEC when I say he was very much loved and respected by everyone. Brian's love of aeroplanes was well‐known and he devoted many years of voluntary work to the Aviation Museum in Port Adelaide, South Australia, which I have visited at his invitation on many occasions.

As all of us in this place know, without the support of our branch members and their families many of us would not be in this place. I wish to put on the record my appreciation of the dedication, hard work and support of the late Mr Brian Houlson, his wife Christine and their children during my campaign in 1995‐96, culminating in the successful election of the new member for Makin. To the family, friends and supporters of Brian Houlson, I extend my sincere condolences on behalf of all members of the Makin FEC, including Newland, Florey, Wright and Playford.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I stand here this evening to try to talk about a great man. I say that because, truly, words almost limit your ability to describe this man and his influence, his ideas and his radical conscience which has so formed this nation postwar. Flip through the papers this morning and the superlatives fly. Newspaper commentators, friends and colleagues have all struggled this morning to fully encapsulate all that Nugget Coombs has done for this great nation. I do not think any one of them has been able by themselves to completely tell everything about Nugget Coombs.

SPEECH.PARA: Nugget passed away on a day when this chamber was in the middle of a heated debate about native title. Native title and the land rights struggle by indigenous Australians was one of the many issues that Nugget Coombs was concerned and passionate about. Native title and the land rights struggle was one of the many issues issue that Nugget Coombs played a central role in. He played a central role in improving the conditions of Aborigines and in so doing once more strengthening the fabric of Australian society and its fair go ethos.

Right into old age Nugget Coombs was campaigning for the rights of indigenous people. I tell you what, he gave curry to our side of politics if he thought we deserved it on this issue. He wrote to former Prime Minister Keating in 1993 when he thought we were going wrong on our Mabo legislation and when he thought we needed stiffening up. I think, though, that he would approve of our stance on the current native title legislation, which is now the centre of debate in the House and the Senate. In the letter to Paul Keating back in 1993 he and his co‐writers wrote:
There is no valid reason why native title cannot co-exist with pastoral leases in most cases.

Dr Coombs letter, which was also signed by Professor David Lea and Mr Greg Crouch, warned the government of the day of the international shame Australia would suffer if it squibbed the issue of native title. In the letter to the then Prime Minister dated 10 September 1993, he warned that any uncertainty being created:
. . . has largely been because many companies are not prepared to take the time and effort to negotiate appropriate agreements with Aboriginal land owners.
The letter went on to say:

If there is uncertainty as to whether native title exists in relation to a particular piece of land, there is no reason why the company proposing to develop that land, or exploit the resources of the land, could not negotiate with those claiming to have native title.

In 1993 Dr Coombs was providing sage advice and acting as a conscience to the Labor government. Labor listened to this famous public servant, who had provided good advice to both sides of the political fence in some 50 years of public activity. Today this advice could be just as aptly given to the current Prime Minister, and I hope he listens.

BREAK.PARA: Prime Minister Howard correctly praised Dr Coombs earlier today. Maybe as a sign of respect, and a symbol of Dr Coombs' greatness, Mr Howard would listen just once more to this great civil servant. Maybe as a sign of gratitude to Dr Coombs in his life's work, Mr Howard will listen to those people whom Nugget Coombs spent a great deal of his time fighting for—indigenous Australia.

In conclusion, for the children of the Depression the influence of Nugget Coombs on Australian policy was exceptionally important. He had responsibility with one Ben Chifley for the postwar reconstruction of Australia. Many children of the Depression went to war without opportunity in life. It was the work of Nugget Coombs with Ben Chifley that gave those young men and women an opportunity in life.

The postwar reconstruction program gave those young men and women the opportunity to undertake some training, to develop a real career prospect in life, and to purchase, through the housing schemes that were available to servicemen, a home and create opportunities for their children. I am pleased to say that my father, who left school at the age of 13, a child of the Depression, was one who clearly benefited, and so did his five children, from the opportunities that Ben Chifley and one Nugget Coombs created for this nation.

I give credit to Nugget Coombs not only from the Australian Labor Party this evening but also from the Ferguson family. I would not be here this evening if it were not for Ben Chifley and Nugget Coombs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to talk about a group of people in my electorate who are very much looking forward to the announcement of Natural Heritage Trust funding because, in my electorate and so many others around Australia, there are numerous activities which need to be undertaken to secure the environment. Everybody knows the importance of areas such as the Great Barrier Reef and Kakadu National Park. Local creeks, waterways and rivers do not get international headlines, but they are equally important.

BREAK.PARA: In the first instance I would like to make a few comments about a particular waterway called Lagoon Creek. There is a very dedicated group of people who call themselves the Friends of Lagoon Creek. Lagoon Creek is a particularly pretty waterway which runs through Caboolture in the middle of my electorate. At one stage it was the entire water source for the town. It was also the place of entertainment. Today, it is chock‐a‐block full of algae weeds from run-off from farms, industry and the burgeoning spread of housing. It also has the pitiful sight of rusted car bodies, household rubbish and, of course, the trolley from the local supermarket which tends to find its way down there all too often.

This group of people are trying to recover this land and achieve its restitution so that it can be here for generations to come. They, along with members of the Pumicestone water and ecosystem monitoring system and the Pumicestone Regional Catchment Coordination Association are working towards ensuring that the wonderful catchment area of the Pumicestone Passage, taking in Bribie Island, all the way from Caloundra through Caboolture to Deception Bay—one of the most pristine area of Australia—is not only maintained in its current condition but also improved and returned to the standard that it was many years ago.

It is not only the human habitation of that area but also the marine habitation, the wildlife and the bird life which have deteriorated as a result of the pollution in this area. It still looks fabulous to the eye, but the reality is that it is degenerating. This is the unfortunate spin‐off from growth in the area, and there has been a deterioration in the water quality and the condition of the local waterways for some time.

Recognising the need to preserve our local waterways, the Pumicestone Regional Catchment Association and the Maroochy/Mooloolah Catchment Care Association have applied for over $200,000 in Natural Heritage Trust funding for two projects, which will include a major data collecting study for the implementation of a regional catchment strategy. It is important that we as a community have a heightened awareness of our natural environ ment and preserve it for future generations, and these people are doing just that throughout the electorate of Longman.

Whilst I believe the recent development in the local area has been welcomed, I call on the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) to fund these studies so that we can stop the rate of deterioration of our local waterways. They are every bit as important to these local residents as the major environmental issues of the day right throughout the nation. I would also like to pay tribute to the work of all those people associated with both groups and recognise the role Caboolture councillor Chris Minetti has played in preparing the funding application.

I donated a Waterwise kit last week to schools participating in an understanding of our catchment area so that the young people coming through, who will be responsible in generations to come for development, will be aware of the importance of waterways, no matter how small they may be. I was pleased that my wife, representing me last week, was able to make a presentation of a water kit to the Bribie Island State Primary School for their efforts and so that they can test the quality of water in our region. It is very important that we do this, that we have an awareness from the youth right through.

This is a community activity which must be supported. This is a community activity which will improve the quality of life for all of those who live in the Longman electorate, whether they live in Deception Bay, Bribie Island, Ningi, Beachmere or in the more rural areas such as Caboolture and Woodford. These people deserve a good quality of life.

It is important that the Natural Heritage Trust, which this government has had the foresight to put together with the sale of one-third of Telstra, be used not only for major projects but also for these important minor projects as well. I am sure this government will recognise the work of these people in their community to improve the lifestyle and the environment and, in doing so, will ensure that the Natural Heritage Trust leaves a lasting legacy not only for this generation but also for many generations of Australians to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent weeks the House and the Newcastle media have seen the increasingly embarrassing and fatuous performance by the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) which reached a crescendo both this week and last evening with the fiasco over chicken meat. One of the things that has been put about, and I think it must be laid to rest very promptly, is this suggestion that, in the time he has been a parliamentarian, he has made wonderful achievements for the area and that somehow this government is supportive of Newcastle and the Hunter. In putting that forward, he has been questioning and quite deceitfully projecting the performance of the previous Labor government.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to mention a few things that were achieved in Newcastle and the Hunter under the previous federal Labor government. I might start with the steel plan in the 1980s which contributed the equivalent of $60 million from the Commonwealth into that region's economy at its discretion. It was not chosen by Canberra, it was not chosen by the parliamentary secretary; it was chosen by local people.

The member for Paterson might consider when he next goes game fishing, as apparently he does, that the wharf at Nelson Bay, in an area that was held by the National Party, was built and funded totally by the federal Labor government. Our concern was to try to generate employment in that region. That $4 million in 1985 dollars on that one project is probably three or four times as much as the total government spending in his term.

But to go further, what about the 1,200 jobs that were generated, 800 in the Taxation Office alone? We have seen 400 of those go in the last year and a half; 400 jobs on the Commonwealth Public Service payroll have been ripped out of our region. Work out the cost of that per year to the local economy and it is quite substantial. If you also look at the downstream spending, you will see that the impact of those jobs alone runs into many tens of millions of dollars, which in turn has cost us more jobs.

BREAK.PARA: I will give a few other examples. The railway station at Newcastle University was fully funded by the Commonwealth Labor government. The ferries on Newcastle harbour were funded by the federal Labor government. The $70 million for the building better cities program was provided by the federal Labor government. The $1 billion minehunter project, which the current government seems to be trying to claim as its project, was established and put there by the federal Labor government. The British Aerospace project for the Hawk lead‐in fighter aircraft was put in place well before this government came into office, and the downstream industries that are being built from that, as was the handover of the Williamtown airport together with $2¾ million in cash for the local councils to actually upgrade it.

They are just a few examples. You can add anything you like: the Centre for Industrial Control Science, the Industry Development Centre, the Cooperative Coal Research Centre and the first ever special program for indigenous medical students. The first ever indigenous doctors to graduate in an Australian university were as a result of a special program funded by the Newcastle University. Perhaps you can top it off by looking at the Newcastle foreshores, one of the very few national bicentennial projects outside a capital city.

That is just a very small sample of the range and depth of our commitment. If the member for Paterson wants to start matching this, he has a long way to go. He has been here a year and a half already, and I reckon he is probably at one or two per cent of what we did in the 13 years we were there.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's generous.

—And I am being very generous, as the member for Werriwa points out. He had the opportunity to help match that in recent months with the report on the iron and steel industry. I have written to the minister asking him to table that report so that we can debate it. I should point out that the member for Paterson did not attend the last four meetings, so he was not part of the report finalisation. He just dumped off on it, as he has with so many other things. These issues are deep and important. They are not fatuous. They should not be trivialised. The region we represent has depth and it has a future, but it does not have much of a future when people like the member for Paterson trivialise all that happens. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neville, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —When the current World President of Rotary International, Glen Kinross—incidentally only the fourth Australian to hold that lofty title—took as the theme for his year in office `Show Rotary cares', a number of clubs took up that challenge across Australia. He was in Parliament House only a week ago talking about polio and his ambitions for that as well. Tonight I wanted to talk about this challenge taken up by the Rotary clubs. Not least amongst those who took up the challenge was the Rotary Club of Canberra City, which devised a genuine but practical program of caring for young unemployed people called `young Australians want to work'—the name says it all. The name is simple enough but it graphically describes the deeply held yearning of the vast majority of young unemployed people who, given a chance, would like to work.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the direction of the Past District Governor of Canberra City Rotary Club, Len Goodman, a carefully crafted but highly professional program was devised. It was launched by Dr David Kemp, the then Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, as recently as 3 September this year. The program was packaged in kit form and sent to 1,200 Rotary clubs around Australia.

The kit consisted of a 14-minute video produced by the ABC; guidelines for employment focused public meetings; press releases and posters; a floppy disk with a formatted running sheet, agenda, evaluation form and certificate of participation; and, as well as that, information on CES and DEETYA. In other words, instead of Rotary's normal fundraising activities, the club went to the heart of the matter, marshalling the various players, devising an effective operational program adaptable to most circumstances but, most importantly, creating the one-on-one contact between young people and potential employers.

In my electorate of Hinkler, the Rotary Club of Gladstone Midday took up the challenge with considerable zeal. Its president, Graham Wilson, and the project coordinator, Gary Frost, marshalled the considerable skills of Gladstone's other Rotary clubs and the services of the Gladstone CES office under its acting manager, Lauren Thomason. The Gladstone CES was totally cooperative and its employer servicing unit, including Mary Mitchell and Leonie Hills, added their skills to the project. The Gladstone media created a community awareness of the program. General manager of the Gladstone Observer, Ned Makim, and its editor, Anne Roebuck, threw their weight behind the scheme. Sue Johnson of radio 4CC, herself a Rotarian, devised a special marketing program.

It was my privilege to launch this program on the local scene at a function held at the Gladstone Yacht Club on 18 September. At that function we played the tape, reviewed the material, heard what Rotaract's Anthea Jensen felt about what the program could do for youth, heard the value of employing young people from Ron Hawkins of McDonald's and heard from the Queensland Chamber of Commerce on how young people can fill staff positions when shortages occur.

BREAK.PARA: That night the first trainee, Colin Cronin, signed up, and his papers were ratified that evening. In the six short weeks since then, 63 young people have found employment in that program. There were 17 full-time positions, 22 part-time positions, three apprenticeships and 21 traineeships—63 jobs in six weeks is a truly remarkable result.

It just shows in this matter of employment how—with inflation down, with interest rates down and with the economy ready to take off again—the communities themselves, through the service organisations working together with their media and their CES office, can start a cycle of confidence and create a new opportunity for young people.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

MIGRATION AGENTS REGISTRATION RENEWAL CHARGE BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 October, on motion by Mr Ruddock:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Martin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1997 , the Migration Agents Registration Application Charge Bill 1997 and the Migration Agents Registration Renewal Charge Bill 1997 it is also my intention to move a second reading amendment which has been prepared for the consideration of the Committee. The opposition is opposing this legislation for a range of reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that, five years after Labor established the first migration system to protect the vulnerable and to try to stop the shonks, the crooks and the rorters, the coalition government unfortunately is about to water down the scheme. The migration agents registration scheme was introduced in 1992 by the Labor Party, aimed at trying to protect people in the community who are vulnerable to exploitation by unscrupulous or incompetent migration agents.

Today, unfortunately, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) is taking the first steps to increase exploitation of the vulnerable. We would respectfully request that the minister read the front page of the latest Weekend Australian. An article there warns about the misuse of our migration scheme by criminal elements. That is of central importance to our consideration of the legislation before the Main Committee for consideration today. In view of that article, the Australian community should understand whether the minister can assure this parliament that the steps he is now taking will not lead to further abuse by criminal elements exploiting our migration scheme.

The migration agents registration scheme set up by the former minister, Mr Gerry Hand, under Labor, was quickly judged a success and was strengthened following the recommendation of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, in June 1995. We believe that the government is now intending to gut the scheme. That is what it is about, gutting the scheme and basically throwing out elements which we believe were clearly intended to make the operation of the migration system in Australia a system based on integrity and, basically, one in tune with the community's needs. To throw out those aspects which made it valuable and useful to the community, to keep the shell and then to have the hide to pretend that the government has kept the scheme is far from acceptable to the Australian community.

Self‐regulation is asking the stronger parts of this sector to refrain from exploiting their position. It would be nice if it worked. However, the reality on the ground is that mostly it does not work. Did this government not state only a few weeks ago that self‐regulation with respect to the relationship between small business and big business was not a goer? It would seem that, where the government believes that there are votes out in the small business community, it is willing to oppose self‐regulation to try to buy back small business's support. But when it comes to protecting the vulnerable in the community with respect to the operation of the migration system in Australia, this is a government which supports deregulation without proper consideration of the consequences of such deregulation.

Was this not because, so the government stated, there was a major power imbalance? I think the role of government is to ensure that we try to correct some of those power imbalances from time to time, not only to ensure that there is integrity in the Australian community but also to ensure that all Australians get a fair go and can operate on the basis that there is a government in place that is committed to ensuring that any imbalances in power are corrected as required from time to time.

Under the bill before the committee for consideration today, it is proposed to delegate the regulation of migration agents to the Migration Institute of Australia. Perhaps if this body really represented the majority of migration agents, this scheme would have some chance of operation. However, the membership of the Migration Institute of Australia currently is only about 10 per cent of all migration agents.

BREAK.PARA: I must say I take exception to endeavours by this organisation in recent weeks to actually seek to negotiate with the voluntary sector fees that they might feel are appropriate for the purposes of registration if they are to obtain the authority as embodied in the bill to operate the migration agents registration scheme in the future. If the scheme is to come into operation, I would have thought that sector ought to be totally excluded from the requirement to pay fees, yet we have these usurpers out in the community seeking to negotiate, even before the bill is properly considered by the Australian parliament, appropriate registration fees.

For the Migration Institute of Australia to take over an efficient scheme for the regulation of migration agents, they will need massive assistance from the department. Minister, your government's own review of the migration agents registration scheme conducted by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs in March 1997 found that:
The current . . . scheme has resulted in the removal from the industry of a number of grossly incompetent or unscrupulous operators who were practising as migration agents prior to its establishment.

I also contend that it has succeeded in establishing sufficient barriers to exclude those who have demonstrated a capacity for behaving unethically. Clearly, the role of government is not only about restoring the power balance but also about ensuring that the system operates on the basis of some ethics.

The scheme as set up at present works to protect the vulnerable against the greedy, and I think that is exceptionally important. Many people who require assistance on the migration front clearly require special protection and a willingness by a government to actually intervene to ensure they are not exploited and, if anything, ripped off by the greedy in the Australian community.

So if the system is working well, why does the government want to change it? Who is pressuring the government to get rid of regulation of the industry? After all, the government's own review also found that the scheme had not adversely affected the competitiveness of the migration advice market. There seems to be no reason to move towards self-regulation other than an ideological reason.

I must say from this side of the House that we are not amazed at this approach to issues judging from the government's current consideration of a range of policy issues. It is a government run by ideology, rather than the proper consideration of the impact of those ideological decisions on the Australian community at large—be it with respect to aged care, industrial relations, employment, a willingness to invest in industry policy and support regional Australia or, unfortunately, on this very sensitive issue, migration.

The changes, I suggest, must be due to some crass ideological bent—to bash the public sector and contract out whatever you can get your hands on. If anything, it is to reward their mates in the Australian community. That is what it is about. You only have to look not just at this bill and the changes on a range of policy fronts in more recent times but also at the range of appointments across many committees and councils established by the Australian government—be it with respect to sporting activity, employment activity, regional Australia or whatever. It is clearly about rewarding mates. That is what it is about.

I also suggest that this is related to the bill currently before the House. It must be so because there is nothing, even in the review which the government bases this bill on, which indicates that self-regulation would be better or even as good as the current system. I understand why some members on the other side of the House get sensitive with respect to these issues. I refer to the fact that the review simply states:
There is no basis for public funding of the regulation of the migration advice industry.

The entire regulation scheme is currently paid for by registration fees. I might take issue with that but, in any event, who pays does not determine who regulates the agents. A government run regulation system funded by registration fees is perfectly feasible and legitimate.

The review also stated that the industry had grown in size, developed a better reputation and had a stronger focus on standards and training. I believe that the issue of training is important. The review states baldly, with no supporting evidence or even argument, that self-regulation is needed to develop industry standards and improve client services. This interesting view immediately follows a paragraph which says that the industry has improved since the advent of the migration agents registration scheme.

The Labor opposition agrees that more training is needed by those who work as migration agents. The bill acknowledges this fact. But, in that context, by cutting funding to the Victorian Immigration Advice and Rights Centre and the Immigration Advice and Rights Centre, the non-profit organisations which provide the bulk of the training, the government has, in effect, cut access to such training which is so fundamentally important to the bill before the House.

Agents employed by the voluntary sector represent 21 per cent of all migration agents. Currently, many of these agents are registered but do not pay registration fees. It is proposed by the bill that employees of these agencies pay registration fees. As I have indicated, I object to certain elements that seek to take control of this scheme in the future, that actually seek to engage people in the marketplace to determine registration fees without proper authority or consideration by this parliament or the minister.

Is this a deliberate strategy by the government to undermine the financial viability of the voluntary sector? It is basically about ripping away from those who really try to assist the underprivileged in the community their capacity to look after the people who really need assistance, while, at the same time, looking after their mates in the broader community.

Those who go to the voluntary agencies—the migrant resource centres, the IARC, the VIARC and the Refugee Advice and Case Work Service—are amongst those who are most needy in the Australian community. They are those who want to sponsor their parents, their children, their husband or their wife. If the voluntary agencies have to pay registration for their employees and volunteers, they will not be able to afford to provide this very valuable service to the Australian community and, more importantly, to those most in need in the Australian community.

The question, therefore, is: in whose interest is it that the poorest of the poor will either have nowhere to go or be forced to pay higher, sometimes exorbitant, fees to the private sector? That is the crux of this bill, forcing the poorest in the Australian community into the hands of the greedy and the exploiters while those who want to bring in someone to take the job of an Australian worker will be able to pay for good advice. Of course they will be able to pay for good advice.

I am not saying that all migration agents in the private sector are greedy or unscrupulous by any means. Many of those who support self-regulation do so not because they hope thus to evade scrutiny but for reasons which they see as valid. However, we currently have a good system which provides some protection for consumers, and I would argue that we are obligated to protect it.

There is a responsibility on this House to seriously consider that question in this debate today. It is about ensuring that, if you have a good system which provides some protection for consumers, you must seriously consider protecting it and keeping it in place. If anything, the House should be debating how we improve it, how we strengthen it, not how we rip it apart.

Let us, as proposed by the bill, ensure that migration agents undertake some training each year to upgrade their skills. On the whole, migration advice cannot be controlled by market driven competition. It should be beyond market driven competition. It is not about selling apples or pears; it is about looking after people, looking after the needy in the Australian community. It is not about dollars and cents; it is about people who need assistance. Most of those who use migration agents, as I have said, basically use them on only one occasion—to apply for a family member or a spouse to come here. There really is not an opportunity to shop around. It is often at a time of desperate need.

The aim of the registration scheme is to protect the Australian community against the activities of unscrupulous agents aiming to rip off the community, not just their clients. Whenever an agent helps a client lie on a form, he is rorting the system. We should not forget that fact because we all see those types of cases come across our desks.

I must say that there is generally on both sides of the House a commitment to ensuring that those types of people are not allowed to rort the system. We also go out of our way to expose those clients and agents involved in seeking to rort and destroy a system that is basically held up in the international community as being a decent migration system.

Every fake marriage, I suggest, is an abuse of our hospitality. Make no mistake, migration agents have arranged fake marriages for clients. They have in the past and they will continue to do so in the future. Every time a prostitute is brought in on a visitors visa, and then applies for permanent residence, the Australian community is rorted; it is being ripped off. Make no mistake, migration agents have arranged this for their clients. They are to be condemned.

Every time a business migrant moves funds into Australia for a strictly limited period, and then moves them out again, the Australian migration system is being abused. As I have said, there are good and bad migration agents. But every time one of these migration agents absolutely rorts the Australian system, then it places further obligation on this parliament to ensure that the system in place is able to control the capacity of those rorters to undermine the integrity of the migration system in Australia. Every time a criminal from overseas comes into this country with the help of someone here, we are being exploited and our safety is being put at risk, as reported in the Weekend Australian of last weekend.

The migration agents registration scheme aims to weed out these unscrupulous, criminal agents, and so it ought. The system ought to be protected, it should be strengthened and it ought to have the support of both sides of the House. By gutting the system you are making it easier for the unscrupulous to function. That is what it is about: making it easier for the criminal elements to come into Australia, making it easier for those who want to rort the system amongst the migration agents—and it is not all of them—to actually undermine the integrity of the migration system in Australia.

I am not saying that the current disciplinary procedure is ideal. However, self‐regulation will not deal at all with the crooks and the rorters. And that is what some of these migration agents are, they are crooks and rorters, they are un‐Australian, and they are working against the best interests of Australia as a nation both domestically and internationally.

We do not object to setting up a mediation process to deal with consumer complaints. That can be done without self‐regulation, and the minister knows that as well as I do. The opposition fears that self regulation would be a backward step and may lead, in actual fact, to deregulation.

Minister, you know, and every MP in this House knows, that electorate staff have quite enough work to do without returning to the bad old days of trying to sort through misleading, wrong and illegal advice to would‐be migrants and their sponsors. More importantly, those hard cases often land on our desks after unscrupulous migration agents have ripped off ordinary people in need, charged exorbitant fees, misled them as to their capacity to assist them on a range of migration issues, and then, having ripped them off, basically said that it is the government's fault—blame the government irrespective of who was in power: `It's not our fault, you go and see your local federal member of parliament, they are to blame—not me, the migration agent; I have just taken your dollars and run, and I will continue to work one step ahead of you with money in my pocket while you and your family suffer.'

Those who are competent and caring agents—the majority, I suggest—have nothing to fear from the current system. The current system is for their benefit because it is about ensuring that those decent agents—as against the crooks and rorters—are out there in the Australian community with a respect and a capacity to operate in a proper way. But the community as a whole has a lot to lose from the dismantling of the safeguards put in place to weed out the shonks and crooks and rorters. That is our fear about the bill before the House today—we go down the deregulation path and it can potentially lead to the shonks, the crooks and the rorters getting the upper hand, unfortunately, with respect to the operation of a system which is basically aimed at assisting the needy in the Australian community. On that basis, as I indicated at the outset, I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"the House declines to give the Bill a second reading, and:

(1) deplores the Government's proposal to self‐regulate the migration advice industry, being of the view that this will open the way to the most unscrupulous agents to exploit migrants' vulnerability and lack of knowledge;
(2) condemns the Government for proposing that voluntary agencies pay registration fees and regards this action as a deliberate strategy to undermine the service delivery of the voluntary sector;

(3) notes that under the self‐deregulation proposal there will be no overall monitoring authority and that consumer rights and protection will be marginalised as the decision makers are also members of the industry association, with no independent overseer to review any decision made;

(4) notes that the reduction in the time allowed to lodge an objection reveals the Government's disastrous failure to ensure a high standard of character, professionalism, expertise and accountability within the profession and that this will further compound the barriers for consumers to complain, as many who have grounds to will be from non‐English speaking backgrounds and will require extra time in order to respond to a nomination; and
(5) is of the view that arrangements should be introduced to continue the present arrangements".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gambaro, Teresa, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for the opportunity to speak today on the Migration Agents Registration Application Charge Bill 1997 , the Migration Agents Registration Renewal Charge Bill 1997 and the Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1997 . This legislation is designed to further enhance the migration program and focuses on the move towards self‐regulation for the migration advice industry. Essentially, the bill is about consumer protection and ensuring that those in need of immigration assistance will have the confidence they need to get a service based on the minimum standard of quality, and that they will be protected. It also ensures that the service is competitively priced and that those seeking that advice will have the opportunity to get redress of a service which may be incompetent or unscrupulous.

SPEECH.PARA: The need for protection in this particular service industry arises because of the extraordinary vulnerability of those who seek to make use of the service. The member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) is not really concerned about the vulnerability of people. He speaks about protecting people who are unable to protect themselves and, clearly, this bill is about protecting those people. I would also like to note for the information of the member for Batman that the government is currently giving more money—some $5 million a year for the next four years—through a grant scheme to help those people most in need, particularly refugees.

This vulnerability is partly due to consumers lacking skills and knowledge in this area, and this was noted in a 1995 report by the Joint Standing Committee on Migration. That report acknowledged the adverse consequences which could flow if people received inadequate or inaccurate advice—the most serious being that the applicants could lose their chance to qualify for a visa or to stay in Australia—so the federal government has long been aware that there have existed inadequacies and loopholes in the present regulatory migration advice system.

It is amazing to hear the member for Batman speak about migration agents in the way that he has, implying somehow that all migration agents act with impropriety. The experience that I have had in the industry is that there are good and honourable people providing good advice and high quality counsel and care for their clients. It was incredible to hear him slur the industry the way that he has today.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some crooks.

—There are crooks in any industry, but the member for Batman is implying that the majority of agents behave with impropriety. I find those views he expressed here today offensive; I am sure that many migration agents have high integrity. One of them, the former member for my seat, the Honourable John Hodges, would find those views very offensive. I know that the previous member for Petrie has an outstanding reputation in this field in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also important to note that early in June 1996, we commissioned a review of the migration agents registration scheme—and I have this booklet here with me today. The terms of reference were agreed to by both the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock). It was the first regulatory arrangement to be reviewed by the Commonwealth as part of the competition principles agreement which were reported in March of this year. The bill is in response to this very comprehensive review.

I would like to highlight who was on that particular review. We had some rather outstanding people on that review. You could not get a more balanced group of people. We had Mr Ian Spicer, the Chief Executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry; Pamela O'Neil, Chairperson of the Migration Agents Registration Board—

TALK.START.PARA: —A former Labor member of parliament.
—A former Labor member of parliament: it is interesting to note that.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Members, please! Order!

—Also we had Mr Ian Tonkin, a Sydney barrister and consultant editor of the Australian Trade Practices Reporter ; Cheryl Webster, a grant‐in‐aid worker for Careforce for the Anglican Home Mission; the Honourable John Hodges, whom I have mentioned: a former member of this House and very well respected on both sides, and Queensland State President of the Migration Institute of Australia, who has worked for many years in this role as a former minister in this area; and Pauline Mathieson, a national committee member of the Migration Institute of Australia. All these people worked very diligently on the report, and you could not get a more balanced group of people.

SPEECH.PARA: In light of today's debate, it is worth while highlighting some of their key recommendations, and I would like to do that now. They reported that the migration agents registration scheme must improve its competency standards. This is what it is all about. It is about competency and doing the job right, particularly in relation to entry level training. It is important to stress that. They said that higher entry standards were needed in the restructuring of registration and the accreditation process. What is wrong with an accreditation process and having a higher standard? They reported that the registration fee scheme should reflect those particular competency skills; that legal practitioners who provide assistance should be required to register as migration agents; and that provision should also be made for an industry‐run complaints resolution service.

The committee said that serious consideration also needed to be given to options necessary for the industry to achieve self‐regulation and to develop an industry standard. The report went on to outline the three models of regulation. The first was voluntary self‐regulation, working through mechanisms, including setting membership criteria which guaranteed that its members met set competency and ethical standards, and adopting disciplinary procedures to deal with members who breached the code. That is very important. When we look at a number of industries that are also increasing their level of competency, why does this industry have to be excluded from that? They should have a well‐developed system and a code of competency and conduct. Other mechanisms were the adoption of a complaints resolution scheme to resolve complaints between members and consumers, and the sponsorship of entry‐level courses and continuing education.

The second model was self‐regulation. This model would see the power to register fall within the precincts of the Migration Act under the auspices of the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs.

The final model discussed was that of co‐regulation, which focused on the linkages between the government and the industry to regulate the industry. But it was concluded that the migration advice industry still needs to mature in order to achieve true self‐regulation. With this in mind, the bill reflects the government's decision to introduce a form of statutory self‐regulation for a period of two years, set to commence in March 1998.

This bill provides for the appointment of a Migration Institute of Australia as the migration agents registration authority, which will have statutory back‐up and departmental assistance, particularly in the area of financial accountability. The referral of instances of unregistered practice and fraud will also fall within the scope of this particular authority, and it includes provisions in relation to performance, financial accountability and also complaints handling.

The amendments geared towards monitoring the competency of agents are being spearheaded by the mandatory requirement for all persons, including lawyers, seeking to practise as migration agents to be registered. As well as the introduction of an annual registration renewal, there will now be a requirement for proof, on application for renewal, of continuing professional development, which includes keeping abreast of the most up‐to‐date regulations, legislation and other migration requirements.

Clearer and more stringent registration will also be set for agents working in the voluntary sector, and that is for agents who do not charge clients a fee. There are some very good people in the voluntary sector who provide good advice. But there are also people in the voluntary sector who need to ensure that they maintain their level of accreditation and give good advice to people—because giving bad advice can have absolutely monumental consequences.

The scheme will now include assistance to be provided by persons seeking to sponsor or to monitor another person for a visa. The term `immigration assistance' will be clarified so as to not include assistance provided by travel agents or translation and interpretation service providers. All of these measures are designed to better streamline applications by persons who seek to register as migration agents—and what is wrong with that?—as well as to protect the applicants.

In the areas of disciplinary measures and dispute resolution, the most significant amendment is that disciplinary matters involving lawyers and agents will now be referred to the relevant professional bodies, which are the most appropriate bodies to deal with these issues. Also, the Migration Agents Registration Authority will be able to refer parties in dispute for mediation, and there will be an enhancement of the relevant offence provisions to bring them into line with the Commonwealth policy on criminal law, which is a very good measure.

It is proposed to introduce a registration fee for those agents operating in the voluntary sector. This has been found to be necessary as at present the absence of a fee for those in the voluntary sector sometimes results in cross-subsidisation in that private sector. To offset the difficulty that those in that sector will have in meeting the costs of registration, the government is going to impose a much lower fee. Also, the Migration Institute of Australia will be authorised to collect fees on behalf of the Commonwealth as a more efficient collection measure.

With the aim of the program being to progress towards self-regulation, there will also be measures to ease its introduction over two years. Agents working in the voluntary sector will have a reasonable time to pay any new charges and agents who are already registered as agents will have two years from the commencement date of this scheme to meet continuing professional development requirements.

The migration advice industry, on the whole, has a very significant role to play. It is essential for the future development of an efficient and streamlined immigration program in this country that these measures be implemented to ensure that there is a competent, affordable, ethical and reputable migration advice industry. Not only is this for the protection of the industry's consumers and the community as a whole, but it is also necessary in order to complement the other wide ranging legislative and administrative initiatives that the government has already introduced into the migration program.

These initiatives form a very tightly controlled package which will be monitored closely in order that the program be more efficient and be more effectively serving both migrants and the Australian people. The government should be commended for comprehensively addressing these broader issues within the program and for its continued commitment to improving the migration program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this debate on the Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1997 , the Migration Agents Registration Application Charge Bill 1997 , and the Migration Agents Registration Renewal Charge Bill 1997 . I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), the shadow minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Before those opposite get too excited about some of the things I am going to say about migration agents, let me make the caveat that I know there are good and bad in every community and that not all migration agents are crooks who rip people off. I am going to speak about a couple of bad examples I know of because they are the only examples I know about. That is not surprising because many of the simple migration cases go through without ever first going to a member of parliament. We do not hear about the simple cases. It is the really difficult cases that go to migration agents. The almost impossible cases go there, and therein lies the difficulty.

I enjoyed the speech of the honourable member for Petrie (Ms Gambaro). She said at the outset that this legislation was all about extra consumer confidence. I take issue with that because I do not think it is going to give the consumer any confidence at all. I think it is going to open up an area that unscrupulous operators will be able to get into and they will operate without the protection that is there now.

Every member of parliament, just as they have five or six basket cases who come and see them when the full moon is out, has their five favourite stories concerning migration rip-offs. As I said before, we hear of these because it is the really difficult cases that go to migration agents. As the member representing the Illawarra and its large ethnic population, so much of my time and my office staff's time is taken up with migration cases and always they are the very, very difficult ones.

The migration agents registration scheme has been in operation since 1992. It was created in response to an alarming number of complaints from the community that unqualified and unscrupulous migration advisers were working in the field. I must put it on the public record that I have always been opposed to migration agents. It is no use saying that it was a government that I was part of which introduced it. I was opposed to the scheme even when we introduced it, and argued against it. Nothing I have seen of migration agents' operations over the years has convinced me to think less unkindly of many—not all—of these people. Yet the government is going to make migration agents subject to self‐regulation. I just cannot believe that: if any group should not be let loose on the public, migration agents are that group.

My personal and long held view is that migration agents should be abolished. I think that they mislead and they build up false expectations. You only have to look at the advertisements in the weekend Sydney papers—I do not know about those in other states—to see that there are always ads such as those I have taken up with successive ministers for immigration, saying that these ads mislead. They say, in effect, `Having problems with migration? See us'—all these issues. And people do go there and see them.

Migration agents can do no more, and most often do far less, than the local federal member of parliament. As the shadow minister has said—and I will illustrate this later—many of these cases that start off with migration agents end up, after the fee is paid, on our desk. It is we members of parliament who have to do the work. I have no objection to that. I think that is one of the roles of a member of parliament, and that is why I have always been opposed to migration agents.

I know that each of my colleagues can, and I suspect will, tell their stories about migration agents during this debate. I have had several shams operating in my area. One concerned Chinese immigrants, who would go to a lawyer who was also registered as a migration agent. This lawyer, after taking their money, would then start harassing my office about approaching the minister about a whole lot of other things. It was so blatant that the agent was pocketing the money and then wanting my office to do all the work that my office decided that we would have no dealing with that lawyer at all. Every time that lawyer would ring up or get people to ring up, we would say, `Are you dealing with So‐and‐so?' If they said yes, we would say, `He has taken on that role for you. Let him follow it through.'

My office made it clear to these constituents that in future they would be required to come and see us before going to a migration agent if they expected us to take up the case. My objection was that they were paying this agent $5,000 but all they got for their $5,000 was a telephone call from the lawyer to my office, putting the case on my desk. It is just unbelievable. This is my argument with migration agents. They are in a business first and foremost; they must promise success to get people to part with their money. Yet they are fully aware that many of the cases they take on have no chance of success.

I do not know why people are saying that migration agents give them all this advice. Many of the cases have absolutely no chance of success. We all know how difficult it is to migrate to Australia today. Over two million people apply to migrate to Australia every year, and what do we take—60,000 or 70,000 people. There are just so many cases that it is just absolutely hopeless. My policy has always been, in the 14 years I have been a member of parliament, that we will fight to the nth degree on a case. We will go and make representation and, if necessary, see the minister. We will make all the representations. But we are always very frank with everyone about migration problems or migration chances.
