When people come to see us, we go through the points score with them. We ask them all the usual questions—any remaining relatives there, the whole thing—and often there is absolutely no chance. Members would know the points system: if it is very close we can say, `Okay, we will have a look at your language skills. We will have a look at your qualifications,' and we will say, `Yes, we will take your second cousin into account. You have an extended family.' We go through all these things with them. But when there are 30 or 40 points missing, even though people cry in your office and so on you have to be honest with them, because sooner or later you are going to face these people and say, `I did everything I could. I went and saw the minister three times, I did this and I did that. But there was no chance.'

Why build their hopes up for 12 or 18 months? It is much better to tell them first of all. We go through the points system; we do everything. We always say to people, `If you really want me to write to the minister or to go and see the minister, I will. But this will probably delay it, because they will have to get the file down from Rockdale'—or wherever they keep it in Sydney—and things like that.

I have always believed that if a constituent says, `You are my local member. I insist that you do this,' or, `that you write to the minister,' I should write to the minister or do whatever it is. But, in honesty, I tell them, `Yes, I will write to the minister, but I have got to tell you honestly that your chances are Buckley's. It might change later on or the policy might be different'—and I go through all of the reasons why we are only taking so few people into Australia. We have to tell them. I believe it is wrong and immoral to build up people's expectations falsely, knowing that there is no chance of meeting what are very stringent immigration requirements.

Only two weeks ago, I think it was, I had a Macedonian business person come in to see me. There are a lot of Macedonian people in my electorate. This Macedonian gentleman had a 44‐year‐old female cousin here on a visitors visa. He came in to see me because, as he told me, he wanted her status changed from visitor to permanent resident. First of all, I said, `There is absolutely no chance. The best you can do is to get her to go back and then apply.' I went on with all the arguments about jumping the queue if they did it. I said, `Whatever government it is, whether it is the Labor Party or the Liberal Party, the minister will not change. They are very hard on this, for right reasons.' I said if they went back and then applied, we would watch it through.

I went through the whole procedure. I asked about the cousin's qualifications, but there were none; I asked about language ability, where the bulk of the family lived and about health; I said that they would have to have a police check—all the things we do. It was obvious that even on the most generous interpretation this woman would not meet the requirements to migrate to Australia—not least in that she had a husband in Macedonia, yet she wanted to stay here. I just said, `We can't do this.' I said that, even if she went back to Macedonia and then applied and came out, it would be very difficult. But there was Buckley's chance of getting her status changed from visitor to permanent resident.

My constituent let me know that money was no object. He said, `Colin, it doesn't matter how much it costs.' I said, `It is not really the money. It is not a case of whether you can support the woman here or not. There are requirements and laws, and if she does not meet the requirements you have got Buckley's chance.' It was not a question of money or of his financial support of the cousin, but there was no way that the cousin, on my reading of the points, could migrate to Australia. It was obvious that the person absolutely did not believe me.

Rightly or wrongly, I do not have many Liberal members of parliament in my area. I used to have a Liberal senator there, and any time people were in a difficult situation like that I always said to them, `Go and see Senator Baume'—as it used to be; he had his office in Wollongong. `Don't take my word for it. Go and see Senator Baume.' So I said to this person, because money was no object to him, `Why don't you see a Liberal member? If you think that I am just saying this because I am a member of the opposition or I do not want to take on the case or something like that, go and see one of the government members in our area or in Sydney. But I suspect that that person would come to exactly the same conclusion as mine.' The plot thickened, however, because that guy then told me that he had been to see a migration agent who suggested he come and see me.

Do you know how much he paid? He paid that migration agent $12,000. Twelve thousand dollars he paid and do you know why he parted with that money? I actually said to him, `Look, mate, you might as well have taken that $12,000 out there on the road and stuck a match to it and burnt it for all the success you are going to get.' That migration agent had promised that person that he would guarantee that that cousin would get permanent residency in Australia. He had given a guarantee. I said, `Did you get it in writing?' He said, `No'. I said, `Mate, before you ever part with money like that, you get something in writing from that migration agent.' He had given $12,000 because the migration agent had promised that they would get that person in. He just could not get that person into Australia. The agent had said he would pull out all stops. I said, `What do you think that person can do that I cannot do as a member of parliament? I can go and see the minister; I can go through the whole thing.' He said, `Colin, he promised me that he would get them permanent residency.'

It is outrageous that these kinds of promises are made and that such huge fees are taken from these people with so little result at the end of the day. The proposal to self-regulate the migration agents industry is yet another blow to those people who are exploited and vulnerable to the snake oil charms of those expensive advisers. The legislation allows the most unscrupulous migration agents to stay in business, to make their unending promises, to keep sucking money out of people who are vulnerable and lack the knowledge of the processing of attempts to remain in Australia.

The legislation provides for the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) to appoint a Migration Institute of Australia, which will be the authority which registers migration agents. Some of the migration institute's responsibilities will be to register applicants and take disciplinary action against registered agents.

On page 44 of the bill's explanatory memorandum, it is made clear that the MIA preparation task for its new responsibilities will be quite extensive. It says that the MIA will need to `prepare to take on a role of industry regulator, including building its membership base'. At this time the MIA is a small organisation with a membership not at all representative of the migration agent industry. At the time of the MARS review in 1996, the MIA membership comprised only 12 per cent of migration agents who dealt mainly with migration registration.

I know that when the shadow minister mentioned sham marriages some people objected. I have seen sham marriages down in my area and I tell you one other area that we ought to look at when we are looking at sham marriages. We ought to look at the marriage celebrants. I had a marriage celebrant in my area and he was marrying people so that they could stay here in Australia. They did not have the requirements and I got him into my office and I went through the whole thing with him. I said, `Look, this person was here on a visitors visa or this and that. They don't meet the requirements. Why did you perform this marriage ceremony?' He said to me, `Because there is nothing in the regulations that says that I, as a marriage celebrant, should check the requirements of people staying here. You check whether they are married or not. You check all sorts of things, but you do not have to check their status in Australia.' They are in Australia as a visitor or whatever it is and they will marry them under the false belief that they will then be allowed to stay in Australia.

I am most concerned also about the attack on the voluntary system. In my area, we have the Illawarra Migrant Resource Centre, which does a lot of good work. We often work very closely with them on some of these cases. Indeed, we sometimes ask people to go in and see them when it is a really difficult case and we know there is going to be no success. We ask them to confirm our reading of the situation. As I understand it—and I could be wrong here—where in the past only one fee has been charged, now each person given advice in that migrant resource centre is going to have to pay the fee. They are not going to be able to do it. I did hear I think it was the member of Petrie say that is was a lower fee. I am not quite sure how much it is, but I mean, this is going to put the—

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll tell you after.

—All right, I will welcome that. As I understand from the quick talk that I have had with the migrant resource centre on this, they are very worried that, if each person is going to be subjected to a fee, then that is going to put them out of that business and they will not be able to afford to pay that fee, especially given the cuts that have been imposed on the migrant resource centres recently. They are not going to be able to afford to pay that fee, therefore they are going to be put out of work. We are going to force these people into the agents who can afford to pay the fee—the wealthy ones. As I have always said, not every migration agent is a rip‐off merchant. But, my God, there are enough of them who are rip‐off merchants to set alarm bells ringing in my mind. I think this is a disastrous step and this is why I so strongly support the amendment moved by the shadow minister.

—I remind members that their opportunity to offer a contribution will be made in accordance with the standing orders. I object strongly to rowdy interjections across the chamber and I advise my intention to enforce the standing orders. I call the honourable member for Deakin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barresi, Phil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —These cognate bills that we are discussing today, the Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1997 , the Migration Agents Registration Application Charge Bill 1997 , and the Migration Agents Registration Renewal Charge Bill 1997 , will provide certainty and security to some of the most vulnerable people in our society, Australia's would‐be or newly arrived migrants and their families. I think it is fair to say that all of us who are speaking on this bill recognise the need for such security and for such need to protect the vulnerable in our society. The problems are well known to us. They have certainly been elucidated quite well today by speakers from both sides.

SPEECH.PARA: There is disagreement about the solution. With that in mind, I, too, rise today to support the government's legislation but oppose the amendments from the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson). In my electorate of Deakin, one in four people, a total of 29,000, were born overseas. Recent evidence suggests their proportion is rising. Over half of Deakin's migrants are from non‐English speaking countries such as Vietnam, China, Greece and Italy. English is not the main language spoken at one in six homes in my electorate. One in 10 local migrants speaks English not well or not at all.

These people faced immense challenges as they prepared to move to this country or in sponsoring their relatives to join them. Trying to understand an unknown system of government and new laws from across the sea is a formidable task for everyone. And it is even harder for those who do not speak English.

These challenges alone prompt many to seek immigration advice from third parties. They have every right to do so, of course, but some people may seek such advice not realising that they do not need it. In some cultures, for example, support from an official is mandatory for dealing with government. Potential migrants from these countries may not realise that they are allowed to apply by themselves in this country. I am aware that cases have also been documented where the migrants somehow gained the impression that a particular migration agent could sway authorities in his or her favour and those migration agents that create that perception, of course, are doing a disservice to their industry at best and are dishonest at most.

Where people have migrated and are trying to support their family to join them, the stress of being kept apart from loved ones for a prolonged period sometimes makes them desperate. Sometimes they are pushed to accept the promises of these unscrupulous agents without question. Sadly, often those most at risk are the ones with the most to lose—those who apply under the humanitarian program. It is heart‐wrenching for them to know that loved ones live in arduous, even dangerous, conditions in their home country. Who in this situation would not seek out every avenue that offers even the slightest chance of successful reunion?

In both onshore and offshore applications, many humanitarian applicants and their families enter into expensive and often futile appeals out of sheer desperation. In my experience, I have found that many people do not, for example, understand that appeals to the Federal Court can only review the way in which a decision was made and cannot overturn a decision made elsewhere.

I am certainly not saying that migration agents in Australia have a widespread problem with ethical standards. Many in the industry, both profit and non‐profit, have been shown to provide high levels of service at reasonable charge. Because of that, I am particularly concerned about the amendments that are being proposed by the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), who talks about self‐regulation as being some sort of recipe for disaster, as being some sort of anomaly out there amongst the professions. He may not be aware of it, coming from an ACTU and union background, but for those of us who do have a professional background, self‐regulation is very common. It is very common amongst accountants, lawyers, even with doctors. You cannot get permission to practise in those professions unless you go through the appropriate self‐regulatory body.

In my own profession too, as a psychologist, we have the Australian Psychological Society that regulates the profession and makes sure that we are ethical in what we do and we achieve the required standards that are set down by the profession. It is nothing new. It is not a recipe for disaster. It is commonplace. As we very well know, migration agents often have another profession, a higher profession. In the case of lawyers, of course, they will not only be part of a self‐regulatory regime for migration agents but also for their own profession at the bar where they operate.

The member for Batman also went on to say that a lot of them are crooks and rorters. I say to him that most of the people out there are not crooks and rorters, but in fact are very good, honourable people who have the interests of their clients at heart. Sure, I agree, as the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) has indicated, that there are a few bad apples that spoil it for everyone. But there are other ways in which to tackle those individuals, and I know that self‐ regulation will do that. These crooks and rorters that the member for Batman refers to are not as widespread as he makes out.

The other point that was raised is that migration agents, because they are crooks and rorters, are allowing criminals, prostitutes and other unsavoury characters into this country. Let me say to the honourable member for Batman that if he wants a bill which is going to tackle every specific issue in regard to migration, then it will be a cumbersome effort at best. There is a bill that will be before the House—in fact, I believe it might even be before the House some time this week; if not, when we come back—which looks at the whole issue of how we control those migrants or prospective migrants who have a character other than that which is seen to be acceptable in this country. I believe that bill will be the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 8). There are other mechanisms available, if the honourable member for Batman has those concerns; but trying to bring it into this bill and asking that this bill cover these sorts of issues is expecting far too much of one piece of legislation.

Australia continues to be seen as a land of opportunity, freedom and democracy by people abroad. Given this reputation, no wonder migration advisory services are in demand. Those operating in this industry should be supported to offer their services and make the most of what has apparently been an underserviced market. Over the past 18 months, I have worked hard to build a good working relationship with the organisations in my electorate that provide assistance to these people. Groups such as the Communities Councils on Ethnic Issues, the Cambodian Community Welfare Association, the Laotian Migrant Welfare Association and other migrant resource groups provide valuable assistance and advice to newly arrived migrants and their families on a not for profit basis.

For the member for Batman to suggest, as he does in his amendment No. 2, that voluntary agents should not be paying a registration fee, is to miss the point of what the registration fee is all about. The registration fee itself becomes an incentive for those voluntary associations to make sure that their standards of operation, their professionalism, meet the requirements of the migration agents registration scheme. Without the fee, there is little control that can take place. The member for Throsby asked what the fees are. The fee for agents will be $1,000, but the fee for the non‐fee charging agents will be $450. So there is a wide discrepancy there between the fee charging agents, at $1,000, and the non‐fee charging agents, at $450.

There is an incentive there, of course. If they meet the benchmarks that are required for levels of service, then that fee will subsequently reduce. Re‐registration, for example, for the voluntary sector agent will then be $350. It is not a burden, as the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) indicated, but certainly something which is manageable within the confines of those voluntary agents—and what better way to make sure that those voluntary agents, too, meet the standards required?

This is a relatively young and fast growing industry. After all, the current regulatory framework—the migration agents registration scheme—was only established five years ago. Unfortunately, it is an industry where a few bad apples have threatened the reputation of all. Of the 4,000 or so applications for registration since 1992, 400 people have been refused registration and another 780 have been deregistered. So there is a deregistration process that can take place.

Many of the people who have approached my office seeking information on Australia's immigration laws tell me that they do so because they cannot afford the thousands of dollars charged by immigration agents. Others have rung my office in tears because they, too, have paid considerable sums and feel that the agent is not taking action. So I am at one there with the story that the member for Throsby mentioned to us. It is not unique to one member's office; it is commonplace. But the solution is not necessarily to introduce amendments, as the member for Batman has, but to support self‐regulation and the bill that is proposed by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock).

Complaints about fees and various unscrupulous practices have been well documented in this House through a series of previous reviews. I applaud the measures contained in this bill that will provide greater protection to migrant families in Deakin and elsewhere by requiring agents to prove that they have kept up with modifications to immigration laws. By improving the complaints process, simple measures, such as mediation, will ease the cost and complexity for migrants and their families while still bringing agents to account for alleged improper actions—and this service will be free.

Agents will be required to provide a statement of services before being able to claim payments. If payment is made without such a statement being received, the client can reclaim the payment in full. So it is an up‐front, transparent process that takes place between the client and the migration agent.

BREAK.PARA: The legislation will continue to ensure that practising lawyers who provide migration advice continue to be governed by the same codes of conduct as other agents. There will be a closing of a loophole that meant people advising on sponsorship or nominations did not have to be registered migration agents, and the establishment of a new body, the Migration Agents Registration Authority, will oversee the new system. There will be a system of penalties for violations which can range up to 10 years gaol for unregistered persons who charge a fee for migration advice services.

These are the sorts of measures that, even with a self‐regulatory mechanism, will ensure that the prospective clients are protected from those very unscrupulous agents that the opposition keeps referring to. In addition to establishing new benchmarks for protecting the vulnerable, today's legislation will also set the scene for future industry self‐regulation without withdrawing that protection.

Sixteen months ago I argued in this House for an extension to the migration agents registration scheme because self‐regulation seemed premature at that stage. I also vowed to keep an open mind to the possibility of self‐regulation. I now feel that the time has come to start offering this industry some additional responsibility, without the government handing over total control just yet.

This brings me to the third point of the amendments moved by the member for Batman. Under the self‐regulation proposal, he says that there will be no overall monitoring authority. What does he think the minister is? The minister is an overall monitoring authority over the entire scheme. He is there and he will be ensuring that not only the principles but the spirit of the legislation, in the way the migration agents perform their work, are maintained.

The changes that we are debating here today will allow the government to reduce the red tape incumbent on migration agents, many of whom of course are small business owners. This is in keeping with our overall commitment as a government to ensuring that small businesses, whatever they are, have government regulation reduced. These changes will challenge those in this industry to continually upgrade their skills and ensure that we do not develop a two‐tiered industry in this country. The legislation will both require and provide the means for the hard‐working people in community organisations to upgrade their skills and ensure that the advice that they provide continues to be of the best possible quality.

It is right that governments should regularly review the regulation of a relatively new and growing industry such as this, and it is right for industries to move towards self‐regulation as they mature. It is also right that those operating in such an industry improve their ability to operate ethically and to work with each other to continue to monitor developments in their field. I look forward to being able to advise my constituents that this government is continuing to look after their interests, and I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dargavel, Steven, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the previous speaker, the member for Deakin (Mr Barresi) talked about self‐regulation not being new or novel, and about the coalition being committed to cutting red tape for small business—in this case, the small businesses of migration agents. The proposition turns upon an assumption that self‐regulation in this industry in particular will be more effective than regulation, notwithstanding the disastrous performance of this industry before it was regulated. That performance has improved under regulation.

SPEECH.PARA: An example in comparison is the self‐regulation by the New South Wales Law Society in this particular area versus that of migration agents as covered by the legislation. There have been almost 1,000 complaints from individuals and agents during the term of the current legislation. Out of those complaints, quite a number of convictions of unregistered practices or unregistered agents, cautions, suspensions and cancellations were effected under the legislation. Those successful prosecutions brought about a reduction in real terms of the number of complaints—as compared with the difficulties that we confronted before the legislation.

Compare that situation with the self‐regulatory practices of the Law Society, which I suppose is a nice comparison. The total number of lawyers suspended by the Law Society of New South Wales, arising from over 1,700 complaints over the entire period of the operation of this legislation, was just one. This is self‐regulation in what is essentially a closed shop—not the Migration Institute, which only covers some 10 per cent of the industry; you could hardly describe that as a closed shop. But you could certainly describe the Law Society as a closed shop. It commands a great deal of respect and has many members. Its degree of success of self‐regulation in this industry resulted in the suspension of just one lawyer. That is how effective self‐regulation has been in this industry. Compare that with the government's statutory regulations, and it is a much more favourable comparison.

Prior to the introduction of the registration scheme by the Labor government in 1992, the provision of immigration advice was always a matter of chance and luck, pretty much. Prior to this time, there was no regulation of the industry other than the limited level of protective provisions in the Migration Act, which focused on misconduct rather than consumer protection. This was not a happy situation for any of the players. The respectable agents were given a bad name by the unscrupulous and ignorant operators.

We can look at some of examples of things that happened before we introduced the legislation in 1992. Some of those were compiled by the Immigration Advice and Rights Centre in their report Free and independent immigration advice which examined data on clients collected between July 1990 and November 1992.

The examples include: an agent who disappeared after being paid for advising a client to lodge an application which could not succeed; an agent who was holding a client's passport because he still `owed' $800 for his advice bill even though the advice he received was wrong; an adviser who advised a client to apply for an entry permit which could never be granted and charged $3,000 for that advice, and when the client complained the adviser threatened to report her to the Department of Immigration. This is a situation where the clients are utterly powerless and the subject of predatory practices.

Other examples include: an agent who charged a couple $4,000 to prepare an application that was never lodged; an agent who charged $1,200 to a person from Russia for assistance with filling in an application for a visitors visa extension which was less than one page long; a solicitor who told a client that his occupation was on the priority occupations list when it was not, and this gave the client a falsely positive view of his chances of immigrating to Australia; an agent who assisted a student with an employer nomination scheme application from which he was barred because of the prescribed non‐citizen ban.

There was also the example of an agent, a solicitor who had been struck off, who gave advice to a woman from Korea about lodging a marriage application on the basis of her marriage to an Australian citizen. When the couple eventually paid $2,500 to the agent he then lodged the application several weeks after the woman became illegal. This meant she was bound to fail and would have to apply from overseas after serving a six-month re‐entry ban.

BREAK.PARA: The situation before the government instituted the legislation in 1992 was appalling. Yes, there is a great deal of room for improvement, all sides in this debate have observed that, but it is my belief that by removing the regulation that has brought down a reduction in the number of complaints we are going to see a return to the bad old days.

The basic aim of this legislation has been described by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) as an interim measure introducing statutory self-regulation for two years in preparation for moves towards full self-regulation after that time. We have the government seeking, by incremental steps, to weaken the system which has been established over the last five years, a system which tries to ensure that consumers of immigration advice can have confidence in the accuracy and timeliness of that advice. However, in the process the government will lose control over the administration of those protections.

The move towards self-regulation was initiated by the review of the migration agents registration scheme which was commissioned by the government in 1996. The review focused on the impact of the scheme on consumer protection and the cost of regulation borne by business. The review found that the existing scheme had achieved consumer protection and had not adversely affected competition in the migration advice market, although there was a recognition that the competency standards in the market could be improved.

We do not oppose improving the competency standards in the market, we just believe that by taking away all the controls and giving them over to an unrepresentative body we will not be able to engineer an increase in the competency standards, neither will we engineer more protection for consumers, and neither will we improve the reputation of this industry which is mired by those unscrupulous agents.

Raising the competency standards across any industry is something that we should always aspire to. Essentially, there should be no difference between the quality of advice provided by any of the three occupational groups in the industry. Therefore, the move to require continuing professional development and education, which the minister advises will be required under the regulations from March 1999, is also a positive move.

However, it is unclear how competency standards will be improved by the introduction of moves towards self-regulation per se. In fact, I believe the focus on self-regulation of migration agents in this context distracts attention from the other issues which could improve the advice people receive on migration matters.

These other issues include the clarification of legislation to make it easier for clients to understand, which is a subject that I raised in my previous speech on this legislation, the continuation of moves by the previous government to reduce the number of legislative changes that may occur in migration law each year, to make it more stable, and, finally, adequately resource the department so that departmental officers have the capacity both in time and information to provide high quality advice to a greater number of clients, thereby reducing the need to have immigration advisers at all. But that is another debate entirely.

In the second reading speech on this bill, the minister pointed out other reasons why full self‐regulation would not be achievable or desirable in the migration industry. The first reason pointed out was that the consumer group which uses migration agents is quite vulnerable to exploitation by service providers. This is due to a number of factors including language barriers, lack of information about the Australian legal and immigration systems, and the fact that they are unlikely to provide repeat business to the advice provider in the event of their application being successful.

That last point is critical because what we do not have here is a free market. What we do not have here is a system where an Australian citizen can just wander between service providers, as they might in the legal profession where the reputations of those providers guides a consumer in the selection of competent advice. Because the consumer does not have any hope of being a repeat consumer, the reputation of the agent is not necessarily as significant as it might be in other industries.

Another reason raised by the minister goes to the composition and operation of the migration advice industry itself. The minister described the industry as `not yet mature.' That assessment raises the question of what it is that will make this industry mature. Nothing has been provided from coalition members and, particularly, the minister as to what it is about this industry that has suddenly become mature or what it is about this legislation that will create a sense of maturity in this industry.

The three main occupational groups in the industry are lawyers, agents in the private sector of the industry and voluntary sector agents. According to the minister, there is only limited cooperation between these three groups and the proposed migration agents regulation authority, the Migration Institute of Australia. Indeed, the institute covers only 10 per cent of registered migration agents. It makes a farce of the concept of self‐regulation when the proposed body to self‐regulate is so unrepresentative.

As I said, it is not like the Law Society of New South Wales, where they managed to effect one suspension. They are a closed shop. The coalition is proposing to hand over self-regulation to a mob that only has 10 per cent membership of the industry. In fact, the minister's speech provides no positive reason for travelling down the path of self-regulation at all. The primary concerns he raised in his speech regarding the barriers of the client group to introducing self‐regulation, and the composition of the industry, are unlikely to change in the next two years, nor have we been provided with any propositions as to why they would change.

Migrants to Australia will always be more likely than Australian‐born people to experience language barriers, unless we move to a discriminatory migration program, which we must avoid. Labor abolished the discriminatory migration program and it should stay that way. They will always be less familiar with the legal and migration systems. They will only need to go through the migration process once, thereby avoiding the consumer protection incentive of possible repeat business for the service provider, as I have mentioned.

Even if we assume that consumer protection factors which were, after all, the primary reason for the enactment of the original legislation are not important to the minister, the other issues of industry barriers to self‐regulation have not been addressed. The minister, in June, stated a commitment to the provision of voluntary or not for profit advice. Therefore, it appears that his goal is to eliminate the voluntary sector and thereby stimulate the for profit sector.

Similarly, it is unlikely that the minister could seriously consider he was able to reduce the representation of lawyers amongst the industry. No government has been able to significantly reduce the courts' influence on the migration program. That is evidenced by the minister's own admission that he is the most sued minister in the Commonwealth. I do not think that that is something that he would be happy about. Certainly, I would not be happy about it if I were in his position. But this legislation is going to turn up the heat even more: there will be more litigation as a result of this legislation because we will not be knocking out the unscrupulous operators as we otherwise would.

Finally, given that the review of the scheme was the first review by the Commonwealth as a party to the competition principles agreement, it is unlikely that the minister will be attempting to be reducing the involvement of the business sector in the provision of immigration advice. Neither is it likely he will be seeking to reduce diversity in the industry overall.

If these three groups are to be retained within the industry, it is unclear how giving 10 per cent of the industry in the form of the Migration Institute of Australia control over self‐regulation will promote competition between the sectors. That is particularly so when complaints against lawyers were able to be referred to their own professional bodies for disciplinary action. How effective has that been shown to be in the past? It has not been very effective at all.

Another concern is that the move to self‐regulation may indicate to unscrupulous service providers—which we as parliamentarians deal with quite often, or with the consequences of their shonky advice—that the government is less serious about maintaining control over fraud and misconduct in the immigration program.

In the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs annual report of 1995‐96, the department showed a reduction in refusals by the registration board and an 8.4 per cent reduction in the number of complaints as a result of a number of factors. The department attributed the increased successful applications for registration to, in its words:

. . . an increased awareness of the standards required for registration, better self‐selection amongst applicants, and a substantial reduction in the number of cases where the applicant was relying on their practice in the industry prior to the introduction of the scheme, to meet entry standards.

That is, the regulations brought about a reduction in the number of either shonky claims or claims that had been made where perhaps they really should not have been. Whilst there are problems in this industry and the legislation should be toughened up, there has been no real reason advanced by coalition members as to why we should take away those things which have stimulated an improvement in this industry.

According to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, the drop in the number of complaints cited in that report is an indication that the scheme has improved standards of practice in the industry. This scheme has only had five years to bed itself down. The figures show that it has improved the industry. For the government to chop and change, and go down the path of self‐regulation at this stage, is inappropriate and risks the positive efforts made by the department to both control the program and protect the rights of consumers. Both are important. Although this bill is not seeking full self‐regulation at this stage, it is explicit that that is the goal.

There are other aspects of the legislation which require consideration in more detail. The bill represents a retreat from comprehensive complaints handling and disciplinary processes towards mediation. This is a worry in that a major aim of the scheme under Labor was to address the power imbalance between consumers and advice providers. It is difficult to see how this is going to be achieved through mediation. The shonky operators who make money out of operating shonkily are not going to be mediated out of their practice. If they do not have regulation to pull them up, they are going to keep doing it.

Another aspect which is of concern is the removal of the cross‐subsidy. Under the current arrangements, volunteer bodies who provide free or not for profit immigration advice already pay significant costs for the privilege of providing immigration advice to consumers who cannot afford to pay for it. The need to ensure that voluntary agents have up‐to‐date legislation and regulations costs at least $500 a year.

We have the government imposing further continuing education costs on volunteer organisations, as well as fees equal to that of profit service providers, who can charge as much as they like to recoup their costs. We have heard quite a lot about the very high charges that are applied. A better prioritisation would be to require continuing education in the sector, but to continue to exempt it from fees.
This question of exempting the not for profit sector from fees was addressed by the minister in his speech in June. He said:

We expect that those people who are offering free advice through voluntary agencies ought to be the subject of supervisory arrangements. They will still have to be registered. They will not have to pay a fee . . .

The minister came into this place and said that the not for profit sector in this industry will not have to pay a fee, but the legislation says that they will. I am not quite sure what the minister is on about frankly. He is saying that they will not have to pay a fee, but it is very clear from coalition members today, and from the legislation, that they will have to pay a fee.

This is clearly designed to run the not for profit sector out of business. And do you know where all the applications are going to come? They are going to come to us; that is where they are going to come. The people who cannot afford to fork out $10,000 for shonky advice are going to come to us. The question then arises as to whether members of this house are going to be covered by the scope of this scheme, but that is a question for another debate.

If the government is really serious about stopping fraud in the migration program, particularly in the marriage categories, then we will need to ensure that the industry is regulated. There is no suggestion that the industry association will be adequately resourced to ensure that the migration agents who specialise in marriage cases are able to be adequately scrutinised. There is nothing in this legislation to provide us with any surety that the institute does have the resources or the capacity—or the commitment, for that matter—to regulate the shonky operators. It is my view that the institute will not administer, to any satisfactory standard, self‐regulation—nor can it with such a narrow base within this industry.

Clearly, self‐regulation for this industry, in particular, is inadvisable. The minister has, essentially, made statements to that effect in his second reading speech. The shadow minister certainly concurs that this is not an industry that we can move to self‐regulate. We need to keep the rules. We need to keep the protection both for the national interest and for the sake of the consumers and we need to make sure that the not for profit providers are not applied with fees as was undertaken by the minister in this place in his previous speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a contribution to this debate on the Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1997 and associated legislation to express the concern on behalf of my constituents and on behalf of many of the voluntary community organisations in my heavily multicultural electorate of Grayndler at this government's legislation and, secondly, to express my support to the amendment moved by the shadow minister, the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), in terms of all three of its clauses to attempt to fix up the government's failure to put forward appropriate legislation before this House.

SPEECH.PARA: Migration related issues are very important in my electorate. My office does a large amount of assistance for people having problems with immigration issues. My electorate also has a large number of community based organisations doing similar work. I am fortunate to have on my staff Helen Rogers, who deals almost exclusively—three days a week—with immigration issues and with the multicultural community.

But this legislation proposes to move the migration industry towards self‐regulation. This is a move which has created a great deal of concern from, in particular, the ethnic communities in my electorate. These groups believe—and I support the view—that the migration agents registration scheme, implemented by the former Labor government, has started to successfully improve standards in the industry. The primary objective of the scheme to ensure that people seeking immigration advice could be confident of competent and ethical advice is now being achieved. Improved protection for consumers will be severely compromised by deregulation at this stage. Now is not the time for deregulation.

Groups concerned with the welfare of migrant Australians, such as the New South Wales Ethnic Communities Council, have made their opposition to this legislation and to deregulation very clear. One of the primary concerns of the ECC is that it is completely inappropriate for the migration agents registration board, which is, essentially, a regulatory industry watchdog, to be exposed to the principles of competition policy. The ECC said in their submission on the review of the migration agents registration scheme last year that:

The ECC of New South Wales believes the application of competition principles abdicates governmental responsibility in migration services to the wider community as a whole. The government has a role to play in ensuring the services provided to the community are provided at a standard that protects people in vulnerable situations. People wishing to migrate to Australia or family members looking to unite through immigration are often in a vulnerable position and may become prey to unscrupulous agents. Migration is a very emotive issue. The ECC of New South Wales believes the government has a duty to protect these people.
I certainly endorse those comments because there can be no doubt that people seeking advice on immigration matters are a particularly vulnerable group in the community.

Firstly, these people are often dealing with issues that concern their loved ones, their spouses or hopefully future spouses, their brothers and sisters, their parents and their children. Often, in these situations, these vulnerable members of the community are susceptible to unscrupulous agents who may well be about lining their own pockets, rather than providing ethical and appropriate services. People seeking assistance often cannot speak or read English, or at least not fluently. This is in an environment where this government has cut back migrant services such as the Adult Migrant English Service. At the same time as there is an attack on the ability of the community to provide ESL services, you have this change which will severely impact on members of the community who do not speak English as their first language.

These consumers are also unlikely to be aware of avenues of redress such as consumer complaint tribunals. So the unscrupulous agents would be fully aware that they have a greater chance of getting away with shonky arrangements and exploitation than if they were dealing with people who had been established members of the community, who had a greater level of language skills and greater connections with legal services. They are also dealing with an immigration process that is completely culturally unfamiliar, and they have no concept of what to expect from agents—about what is acceptable and what is not acceptable.

BREAK.PARA: The current scheme should, as a minimum position, maintain the current level of regulation. Indeed, I think, there is a case for tightening regulation as opposed to the deregulation which this bill proposes. I am not suggesting that all migration agents are unscrupulous, but there are certainly some who are. The fact is that, as a parliament, we have a responsibility to defend and protect the interests of intending migrants, their families, friends and employers.

To make the scheme more accountable, there are two points to make. Firstly, there are a number of migration agents operating who make unrealistic promises to clients. I am sure that all of the representatives in this chamber today would have specific examples of cases where constituents have come to them in that situation. I intend to go through a number of cases later on in this debate.

The action of these agents ensures that, although the case is doomed to failure, it will drag on for as long as possible, because the objective is not to assist the people requiring help and advice. The objective is to maximise the profit for the migration agent. The longer the case, the further it can be drawn out and the more money can be demanded from these vulnerable people.

In order to achieve this dragging out process, clients are often advised to apply for visas that they have no chance of getting. When the primary decision is finally made, the agents then use the review processes to further extend the case. In the meantime, clients are on bridging visas that allow them to remain in Australia and usually to work. For clients who cannot work, the situation is even more dire. This not only creates unnecessary delays for other, more genuine applicants who would have an entitlement to permanent residency but this practice also gives clients unrealistic hopes about gaining that permanent residency. They can waste years of their lives—and thousands of dollars—when they could be establishing a life for themselves elsewhere.

Also, agents can mislead applicants into believing that their case can be processed onshore when they are in fact banned from doing so under section 48 of the act, having previously been refused a permanent visa onshore. In these cases, the applicants may well be eligible for a permanent visa, but only if they apply offshore. When they are not told about this, they can waste both their time and the department's time with an invalid application.

You only have to look at the number of Pacific islanders with no grounds for permanent residency who applied for protection visas after the 1987 coup in Fiji. Many of these people were advised to do so by migration agents, particularly, I believe, by one I will call M, who is now deregistered. There also needs to be tighter regulations to prosecute people who are posing as registered agents. At present, the department must have proof that the bogus agent has helped someone in Australia.

I want to run through some specific examples of disreputable agents that have come through in my electorate. I obviously will not be using the real names of my constituents, as I certainly want to respect their privacy. But I can assure members that this is but a small sample of people who have come to my attention in recent times.

The first example I will give is that of agent S. This woman, who is an agent, has caused great problems for two of my constituents—a couple. I will call the male M and the female B. M is a Fijian national who is barred under section 48 of the act from applying for permanent residence onshore. Agent S was handling the case and told the couple that they could apply in Australia. She held on to the file for six to eight months before finally lodging the application. Soon after, the couple were told the application was invalid—not surprisingly.

M then went to Fiji to apply there. His wife is 45 years old and desperate to have a child. She is running out of time, and now her husband may be in Fiji for almost a year. If they had known this, he could have gone back 12 months ago, applied in accordance with the proper processes and, hopefully, he would have been back here by now and both of them would have been settled together. The agent involved has been reported to the department and I believe they hope to prosecute, which would indicate that this is not the only case that this particular unscrupulous agent has mishandled.

The second example I will give is that of someone who is not a registered agent but passes himself off as one. I will call him T. He is basically completely incompetent and has wasted hours of staff time at the Rockdale office of the department. He has taken money from many of my constituents and has produced no results.

One particular case involved a family who were trying to get their brother back to Australia. T took their money and gave them false hopes when the case was hopeless. The boy in question had been criminally deported after serving a sentence for manslaughter. He will never be allowed back into Australia, and that is appropriate, yet still this person has been accepting money from this family. This person posed as a solicitor.

In another example, he took $5,000 in advance to handle a preferential family case. He guaranteed the case would be finalised in six months or the money would be refunded. Of course, that was a verbal guarantee. Two years later when we asked for the money back on behalf of the constituents—my staffer assisted the constituents because they did not have the language skills to draft letters themselves—he refused and sent them threatening letters back. Further investigation showed that this person was fraudulently posing as a solicitor. He was not a solicitor, but because he happened to be of the same ethnic group as the people who were applying he was using his position in the community to exploit these people to the tune of $5,000.

Another example is someone who is now disbarred and was prosecuted by the DPP with the help of evidence from one of my constituents. We have not got the result, so I am not sure if the case has been successful as yet. He submitted an inadequate application which subsequently failed, due to his incompetence, and for which he charged thousands of dollars.

We see these cases, not yearly, not monthly, not weekly, but just about daily. And the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) knows, because I have had discussions with him personally—and so have my staff with his departmental officers—and he knows that there are literally dozens of these unscrupulous agents out there ripping off people. And, the solution is not to say, `That is occurring. We will let them run their own show.' The solution is certainly not that, and that is why we have moved the amendment before this House.

Another major concern I have with this legislation is the costs associated with registration—and section 2 of the amendment moved by the member for Batman covers this very adequately. I am sure that the will give that particular clause a great deal of thought before deciding to support it. I know that he will also be concerned about community groups that currently offer free advice to migrants.

In my area there are a large number of these groups carrying out excellent work with intending migrants and their sponsors. Community groups include the May Murray Neighbourhood Centre, just down the road from my office, which has workers from the Vietnamese, Arabic, Pacific Islander, Greek and Chinese communities. They are all working damned hard for very little money themselves, it must be said, because they are honourable people who care about the community. We have migrant resource centres at Ashfield and Campsie which—when the migrant resource centre at Ashfield is not busy helping the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit) with his internal party activities—does good work.

Other groups assisting migrants in my electorate include the Arabic Welfare Association at Bankstown. We have the Australia Lebanese Association, and the Newtown Neighbourhood Centre, which has a number of workers from similar communities to those of the May Murray Centre but also has a Yugoslav community worker who does a great deal of work out there. And we have, of course, the Immigration Advice and Rights Centre. For groups with a number of multilingual workers, you might be talking about having to register half‐a‐dozen agents.

It is vital that these services be retained. Not only do they often offer multilingual services, but they can also be accessed by people who are financially disadvantaged. These communities, as a result of this legislation, will have to choose. They will have to charge fees for that advice, or stop giving it, and this will force many community organisations, already under severe constraints with cutbacks from government funding, out of offering that advice. It will mean that their clients will be either queuing up at our doors—at the offices of members of parliament—or, because they are not aware of those services, they will seek assistance from private agencies. That may well be okay if they go to the right ones, but in a deregulated environment there will be more shonks out there. The community sector, the non‐profit sector, must be exempted from the registration charges in accordance with the minister's comments—but not in accordance with the act—and thereby be excluded from these charges. The non‐profit sector must be excluded.

Other issues of concern with these bills include the lack of a complaints resolution procedure. The provision in the bill for a complainant and agent to be referred to a mediator is a poor substitute, and it absolutely ignores the power imbalance between an unscrupulous agent and a vulnerable client who may have a poor grasp of English. The provision of a 10‐day period only for consumers to lodge objections is an onerous responsibility when you are talking about consumers who are not aware of their rights. If they find out two weeks later, it is too late. This bill represents a conflict of interest where the monitoring body, the regulator, is another association member. If there is one area where self‐regulation should not occur, it is here.

I am also concerned about the bill because it will impact severely on some of the most disadvantaged of my constituents. Now that the migration agents registration scheme is starting to work well, we should not be cutting it back. The government should be building on and strengthening the scheme, but I guess that would not be likely. It would certainly be easy to get the impression that the Howard government is not really fond of migrants, based on its performance to date. The fact is that it is consistent with their cynical exploitation of the Hanson agenda, their preparedness to step back and their failure to show leadership on the issue of race in this country.

If you need a model of where deregulation goes to, based on ideological creed rather than commonsense, you can look at a number of examples. Take the Victorian Premier's example of deregulation of the health system, where you now have salmonella outbreaks, and ambulances just do not show up after they have been called. That is the sort of world that we live in when we have deregulation in an inappropriate fashion.

I conclude my comments today by saying that the amendments moved by the member for Batman are entirely appropriate and deserve the support of this House. This House should be about protecting the most vulnerable people in society, and certainly that is the objective of the amendments. Now is not the time for greater deregulation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had the opportunity to speak on the area of the Migration Legislation Amendment (Migration Agents) Bill 1997 on a number of occasions and I will not unnecessarily detain people today. I have also had the opportunity of course to participate in the 1995 inquiry by the joint committee in relation to this field. I would have thought that, whilst the current Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) at that period was part of an opposition group that essentially did support deregulation, the evidence before the committee was in general extremely poor. From recollection, the only group that was actually critical in any real fashion of the operation of the board was the Springvale Migrant Resource Centre, or some such similar title, who—quite frankly—under examination, were less than convincing. In other words, the main thrust of that inquiry was that there should be a three‐year extension and a review, as a compromise between the two parties at that stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that there are positive aspects to this legislation. Certainly, in regard to sponsorships and nominations, a loophole that was in the previous legislation is now being tackled. The previous government certainly was aware of that, and I would be very supportive of that change. Similarly, it is quite rational and sensible that travel agents who give very minor advice should not be picked up by the legislation. There are some, as I say, positive aspects to it.

However, I really do question the fundamental thrust of deregulating this industry. Many previous speakers have indicated that it is a very unequal balance in this particular field. It is not a situation where there is always actually competition. The reality is that various ethnic communities tend to go to a practitioner who is of their particular ethnic extraction. So, to some extent, there is a degree of monopoly in certain fields. Obviously, as people have indicated previously, people are indeed very vulnerable. They are very desperate: they come from countries that have far worse social and economic conditions than we do, they are prepared to basically do anything to escape that plight and they will grab at any straw to try to stay in Australia.

We are well aware of some aspects of this area. The member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) earlier indicated the amount of money that these people charge for very little work, and the degree of incompetence in the field. That is not to deny that there are some very capable people and some very genuine practitioners who, at the same time, have a slant which talks about human rights and about the interests of their clients. But the area has been characterised by a large degree of opportunism and very mercenary attitudes by many.

I want to also say that, if you are realistic about this field, you have also got to admit that often the clients themselves are just as guilty and are often part of the conspiracy to basically undermine Australia's migration regulations and laws. We should not always assume that, in each and every case where the agent launches ridiculous or preposterous claims, it is not without the connivance of the client. Often, these people are very willing parties, and that is a fact of life which should not be ignored.

The migration agents registration scheme review is less than convincing about the need for change. As other speakers have indicated, this is more driven by ideological requirements, a thrust by the government which simply does not like a government role in the field, and it is a repeat of what we have seen through other sectors of the economy.
In fact, one key finding states:

. . . in the absence of regulation, the market for migration advice has tended to operate imperfectly with consumers bearing unacceptable cost in terms of exploitation and inappropriate practice by a sector of the industry. . .
Another finding was:

. . . that the Scheme has provided a measure of consumer protection and . . . its credibility as a consumer protection mechanism has strengthened somewhat in the time since the Joint Standing Committee on Migration (JSCM) conducted its review of the Scheme.

Furthermore, the scheme has not adversely affected competition in the migration advice market. The only real point they made was the need for further training in the field, and I do not dispute that. That has got nothing to do with whether we hand over control of this industry to a body that represents practitioners who themselves—and the minister has often admitted this—are often very questionable. The report itself makes clear they only cover 10 per cent of the industry and, given the nature of the people that both sides of parliament have questioned, it really is a matter of conjecture as to whether we can rely on them to properly police the industry. The review certainly is not very decisive and convincing in regard to the need to hand it over to this group. It states on page 31:

There are limits to the incentives that government would be able to provide to encourage agents to join the industry association both in times of restraint in government spending and in the migration law context.
It further notes that the association was:

. . . unrepresentative of the three distinct occupational groupings in the migration advice industry. It will become more difficult to establish consistent professional standards and to coordinate activities such as entry level training.
It notes on page 33:

At this stage, the industry has a disparate nature and the industry association has only limited coverage and as a result, the body that takes on the role of industry regulator may face legal and other challenges.
The minister is postponing the final drift towards them controlling the industry but I do not think a very strong case has been made out so that they should be the paramount force in this industry.

The minister might have been pushed in this direction by others and there might be a very tortuous process of getting there, but the fundamental thrust is to basically give management of the industry over to this group, which his own review states is not very representative, and I do not see any major evidence that it is going to become any more representative.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the thrust of Protecting the vulnerable , and you were party to that.
—What is the thrust, Minister?
—I would ask both the minister and the member for Reid to direct their questions through the chair. I am here. The member for Reid and the minister will direct their comments through the chair.

—As I said, there is no real evidence from the minister's own inquiry. It was chaired by Mr Ian Spicer, a person who has a predilection for this kind of concept. He has a long-term record of support for deregulation, believing that it is essentially the ant's pants regardless of the nature of a particular industry or the problems of those who are in it.
—It was chaired by Senator McKiernan.

—You are very selective in your reading of that report, and you, as a member of it, would be quite aware that that is not the major thrust of that inquiry at all. The essential thrust was for a continued government presence in the field.

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned some admirable aspects of the legislation earlier. I think the need for training in the voluntary sector is also commendable. One cannot just take the view that these people are there for the community benefit and therefore we can allow them to be untrained and unskilled. I very much commend the government for going in that direction.

However, the idea of forcing voluntary groups to pay is questionable. Occasionally, you might get people who put their ethnic loyalty before adherence to our laws, and there are questions about some of the advice given, but to ask these groups to pay—groups that are there mainly for community purposes, mainly to help people in dire circumstances, mainly to help people who do not have knowledge, mainly to help people who do not have the language—is undermining their operations. Asking them to pay is not a move in the right direction.

The situation is that the earlier report which the minister cited—that is, the joint migration committee report—was not quite as fulsome in the points that it makes. In giving its account of the industry in paragraph 3.53 on page 53 of the report, the committee noted:

A common theme in submissions was that regulation of the migration advice industry is necessary to ensure consumer protection and the maintenance of appropriate standards within the industry. IARC, for example commented:
. . . a regulatory scheme is necessary to support the reputable people working in this area as well as to eradicate the unscrupulous and incompetent operators.
Just after that, at paragraph 3.54, it noted:
In some submissions, it was argued that regulation of migration advisers is required because of the vulnerability of persons seeking immigration advice.

. . . immigration is a field which has some unique features which merit special regulation in that the client base is, more often than not, in a particularly vulnerable position and this is the case even with clients who can speak English fluently and are highly educated.
Further, at paragraph 3.82, page 61, the committee noted:
Statistics obtained by the Committee support a finding that the achievements of the Scheme relevant to its objectives have been chequered.
Quite frankly, the review that the minister has commissioned makes a similar point about the performance of the current system. The paragraph continues:

On the positive side, around 600 persons either have been denied the right to practise as migration agents or have decided to withdraw from seeking entry to the industry. In addition, the avenues for developing expertise in migration law have increased noticeably, with various courses and seminars now being conducted at a tertiary level and within the industry itself.

As I say, this is not really driven by an analysis of the industry. It is not driven by a conclusion as to what is best for the industry; it is driven because the government essentially believes that competition policy should rule. It does not analyse the particular nature of the industry. It does not have any understanding of the special problems faced by these people. It essentially opens the floodgates for exploitation. It turns over control to an unrepresentative group that includes these same people that both sides of the House are often critical of, and it really is a very questionable direction.

It is also of a concern to me personally—and other speakers have raised this matter—that after Cunliffe, and the victory of the department with regard to regulation of lawyers, I do not have the confidence that the minister seems to have in the ability of the Law Society, and other bodies, to police those people in this field. Quite frankly, I have not seen in the media or heard on the public record much evidence that these bodies are all that efficient in policing their own members. Obviously, there is a degree of self‐interest in the image of the industry in making sure that, often, these complaints are minimised.

I believe that the scheme has worked. There are concerns that perhaps the onus is such that people often do not bring forward cases. I could probably be accused of it myself: I see activities by migration agents that probably should lead me to lay complaints but I guess there is a concern that, with the requirements of evidence, et cetera, it will not accomplish very much. One of the failings in the industry is that we have not been proactive enough in making sure that people feel that they can be successful in pursuing the more dubious practitioners.

But, on balance, we have a situation here where there is a need for the government to have an overview of the industry. I an not only concerned—as I said earlier—with the nature of the practitioners but I also believe that it is very important for this country, and for the integrity of the system, that we are proactive to the fact of life out there that many of the clients are often just as questionable in the way in which they launch claims.

The government should be very proactive in making sure that we give a signal to the industry that launching claims to buy time, and launching claims that manipulate Australia's refugee and humanitarian aspects, are not to be condoned. As I said earlier, I commend these amendments. I do not think the minister or his review or the review by the previous joint migration committee have made any case whatsoever for turning over control of this industry to an unrepresentative body in a field that both sides of politics knew would require, initially, strong intervention to police it. No case has been made out. It is essentially driven by an ideological position and does not analyse what has happened under this current scheme or the solution to the problems that are there.
Motion (by Mr Sercombe) agreed to:
That further proceedings on this bill be conducted in the House.
