SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin, Jenny, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case, as all members of parliament know, that youth suicide is one of the most intractable social problems facing our community today. It is however also true that it is not a new problem. All the statistics that were presented at the seminar that we had suggest that the rates of attempted and completed suicide among young people are increasing. But it is still very difficult to measure, given that many suicides used to be reported as accidents because of the stigma that previously applied to suicide. Indeed, experts at the committee's seminar believed that the current statistics also underestimate the real extent of the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Suicide affects young people from all socioeconomic and ethnic backgrounds in our country, although we do know that certain groups are at greater risk. Completed suicides among young men are four times higher than for young women. Some have attributed this to a greater confusion among young men about their role and their failure to adjust to women's greater equality. In fact, the explanation seems to be much more straightforward. Sadly, it is the case that many young men complete their suicide attempts because they use immediately lethal weapons, especially guns. More young women use drugs and poisons from which there is a greater chance of resuscitation. Were accurate statistics available on suicide attempts, rather than completed suicides, they would be more likely to show a smaller variation between the sexes. From my point of view, to focus on the gender differences sometimes clouds the issues.

Experts at the seminar identified a number of groups at particular risk. They included young people in rural and remote areas, young Aboriginal people, young people confused about their sexual identity, those suffering from mental illness—particularly depression—and those suffering the effects of family breakdown. It is very true, as all who have contributed to this debate have said, that youth suicide is far too important an issue for political point scoring, because all parties are concerned about the problem and are committed to tackling it. Both the current and the previous government have allocated resources to initiatives designed to reduce its incidence.

Some other initiatives of this government will also, I believe, contribute to a reduction in the incidence of completed youth suicides. The most important of these has been the gun buyback scheme which, by reducing the number of firearms in the community, will reduce accessibility to guns, among some young men at least. For this, we can be very pleased. Given that this is the preferred and the most lethal method of suicide among young men, it is to be hoped that it will result in the reduction in the number of completed suicides for this group.

There are other measures particularly affecting young people in rural and remote communities that do however remain of some concern. Many of these communities are suffering significant hardships. These are not just from recent changes. I am not trying to apportion any blame but it is the case that many communities in rural areas are facing significant hardship from the closure of services. At a time when young people are calling out for help from these services, we really need to make sure that they are provided.

BREAK.PARA: We do know that young Aboriginal people are at particular risk of suicide and many of the programs that are designed to help these young Aboriginal people in their communities really need our support. We must, of course, through both the Wik debate and our response to the stolen children report, acknowledge the damage that has been done to Aboriginal people by all past government policies and begin the process of reconciliation. Without that, the most important thing, it is very hard to imagine how we might begin the very long process of overcoming what is the serious despair among young Aboriginal people, which too often manifests itself in deliberately dangerous behaviour and sometimes suicide.

We also learned at the seminar about the contribution of anxiety and confusion about sexual identity and sexual orientation in triggering suicide among young people. I understand that there has recently been a poster and a booklet prepared by the Western Australian AIDS Council aimed at sexually confused young people contemplating suicide. It is very important that we face up to the problems that young people have in confronting their sexual identity and their sexual orientation and that we actually take it upon ourselves to do some of the things that might be seen to be unusual that encourage people to talk to others about these matters of confusion and concern.

We do owe it to our young people to support any measure which might reduce the incidence of youth suicide in this country. Often that will mean that we have to be more innovative in our approaches, and that might sometimes challenge our particular views of the world—those of people of our generation, I mean.

We need to support initiatives which have been shown to work and to look at other options in cases where they have failed. The committee seminar did provide some very useful insights into past successes and also some directions for the future, for example the need to provide a more user-friendly approach to counselling and mental health services for young people themselves and for those to whom they are likely to turn for support.

Seminar participants also pointed to the need for all hospitals—and I think this was a very important point that was made—to institute follow‐up care to young people who have been discharged following a suicide attempt and to the need to support families caring for a child at risk. There is a need to realise that the families where we have children who are attempting suicide are also going through a very difficult time and they are in great need of support.

We are gradually learning more about youth suicide and how to deal with it, and the seminar that was conducted by the committee has contributed to that process. I certainly commend the report on the seminar to all members of the House and support its recommendations. Certainly, from our side of the parliament, we will be seeking to work very cooperatively with other members of parliament to ensure that the incidence of suicide amongst our young people is reduced. Thank you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd, Jim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased today to have the opportunity to speak on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs report called Aspects of youth suicide . I have waited a number of weeks for the opportunity to speak on this report.

SPEECH.PARA: Youth suicide, in fact suicide of all ages, is a national tragedy. As reported in paragraph 17 of the report, in 1995 there were 350 young male suicides and 84 young female suicides. Members of the committee were shocked to hear that children as young as 12 had attempted suicide.

BREAK.PARA: On the central coast of New South Wales, which includes my electorate of Robertson, the suicide rate for young people is twice the national average. It is so easy to talk about the facts and figures and the statistics, but each and every single one of these young people causes immense tragedy and trauma—not only to themselves but to their friends and to their family and to the community in general.

Even before I was elected to the Australian parliament, I met with Mr Eric Trezise, a central coast resident who is at the forefront of the fight against youth suicide, and suicide in general. Mr Trezise had been working hand‐in‐hand with the central coast coroner, Mr Bryan Wilson, and they convened the first central coast suicide summit in early 1996. This, to my knowledge, was the first community initiated summit on this issue.

Some years ago, Mr Wilson, the coroner, recognised the fact that the central coast was having a high proportion of deaths by suicide. He was concerned that there were no identifiable records kept for each region on suicide and youth suicide. It was Mr Wilson who first started keeping records on suicide deaths. That is one of the flaws, and I am distressed to hear other members say, `We have tried to identify what the youth suicide problem is in our particular area.' In fact, there are no statistics in their areas, broken down by region or electorate, to help them identify the problem or how great it is in a specific area. Mr Wilson is possibly the first coroner in Australia to recognise that fact and to have records going back a number of years to help with this problem.

The central coast community recognised even then that we were in the grip of a major epidemic and, as a community, we had to act to do something about it. The central coast suicide summit was attended by local politicians from all sides of politics and by representatives from almost all community groups on the central coast. Approximately 300 people attended that meeting.

The summit made a number of recommendations, which I had the pleasure of forwarding to the then Minister for Family Services, the member for Pearce (Mrs Moylan). As a result of this report and submissions made by many other members throughout Australia, members of the committee identified Australia's high rate of youth suicide as a problem that needed to be highlighted in the parliament and brought into focus by this committee.

The aspects of youth suicide seminar was convened on 28 February 1997, in order to gather information such as that collected at the central coast suicide summit to give committee members a comprehensive overview of the issues involved. The seminar also provided an invaluable opportunity for peak health and community groups, local organisations, youth workers, academics and professionals to exchange information about the suicide prevention programs throughout Australia. Among the invited guests was Mr Eric Trezise. At that seminar, I had the opportunity of introducing Mr Trezise to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). Mr Trezise had the opportunity to put his views and his concerns about the situation on the central coast directly to the Prime Minister. I would also like to put on the record that I was a participant at the seminar and found it very valuable and informative. Unfortunately, my name was omitted from the report.

The Central Coast community is not standing still on this issue. We are not waiting for governments to take the lead. As a community, we are taking the lead. Only recently, I attended the launch and had the opportunity of addressing the audience at the launch of the Central Coast Suicide Safety Network. The Central Coast Suicide Safety Network was launched by the Premier of New South Wales, the Hon. Bob Carr, who has agreed to become the patron of the network. The launch was attended by over 300 concerned community leaders, as yet another step in the fight against youth suicide and suicide in general on the central coast.

The aims of the Suicide Safety Network are: to raise awareness of the tragic loss of life to suicide in the central coast region of Australia, with emphasis on all age groups; to make the public and the governments—local, state and federal—aware of the needs for a collaborative and concerted attack on this problem; to draw attention to the factors which play a role in attempted suicide and to foster appropriate prevention and support initiatives; to highlight the suffering of those bereaved by suicide and those distressed by attempted suicide, and to encourage self‐help groups; to install a direct access telephone service responding to suicide crisis calls; to establish a psychological and sociological autopsy suicide case review panel; to promote trial and pilot programs aimed at reducing the incidence of suicide and attempted suicide amongst all age groups; and to solicit funding and resources to enable these programs to become reality. You can see that the aims of this network are very comprehensive.

One of the major contributing factors identified in the report Aspects of youth suicide is isolation and loneliness. In paragraph 41 of the report, the committee was told that any kind of youth support service must be targeted appropriately, otherwise young people will not access the service. Professional centres requiring appointments during school or work hours, or where a payment is required, will not meet the needs of many young people. Telephone lines, such as Lifeline, are also a valuable resource as they can provide 24‐hour assistance and provide immediate counselling and contact to those young people at a time when they are most vulnerable to suicide.

I am aware that under the Here for Life program the government has allocated over $1 million for improving communication networks among suicide prevention workers and coordinating information dissemination. In the 1996‐97 budget, under the national youth suicide strategy, the government has provided over $19 million over three years to be spent in this area, including $6 million to Lifeline and Kids Helpline for the telephone counselling services.

This is an admirable initiative and is to be commended. Current funding for youth suicide prevention amounts to $30 million, and the committee recognised that while this amount is significant much more still needs to be done. This includes research, coordination, education and counselling services. In paragraph 55 the committee recognised that consideration needed to be given to the possible reallocation of some of the existing funds.

We on the Central Coast of New South Wales have been advocating for some time the establishment of a specific suicide prevention advisory phone counselling service for the Central Coast. It has been identified by a number of those who have been affected by this tragedy that the most effective way that the Central Coast community can help stop this tragic waste of human life is to have this specific phone counselling and assistance service.

We have the premises, we have the trained staff, we have the volunteers on the Central Coast who can provide this service. What we do need is government funds to fund the service. I would appeal to the Minister for Family Services, Warwick Smith, and the Minister for Health and Family Services, Dr Wooldridge, to consider looking at our submission from the Central Coast for the provision of this telephone counselling service. I have already had discussions with Dr Wooldridge and, of course, like every Australian, he is concerned about the suicide problem that we have in Australia, not just the youth suicide problem.

Whilst youth suicide is receiving a great deal of coverage, and it is a high profile concern to everybody, there is a major problem—and we have identified this on the Central Coast—with men aged between 25 and 45 who are not coping with the stresses of life. They are not coping with the responsibilities, as they see it, of raising families, of mortgages or losing jobs. They are what we call on the Central Coast the hidden tragedy of suicide. They are the people that cost our community far more than anyone else. The loss of the life of a person in the prime of their life, when they have children or family responsibilities and work, and the loss and tragedy for the community that are caused by someone in that age bracket taking their life are immense. It is something that we on the Central Coast wish to highlight—not only the youth suicide program.

I know that Dr Wooldridge is looking at what we are saying and at the submissions that we are putting up. Very shortly I will be bringing a committee from the Central Coast, including our local coroner, Bryan Wilson, and Mr Trezise and a number of other leading people in the field, to meet Dr Wooldridge to put forward our ideas and our views on tackling this problem again.

I have waited a number of weeks to be able to make my comments on this report. It is an excellent report. I know that the government has acted on some of the recommendations and certainly will be acting on more of them. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs report on the seminar into aspects of youth suicide, I would firstly add my words of commendation on the deductions of the report. It is a useful document and the recommendations are of value.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like also to express a personal appreciation to those people who took part in it. The seminar presenters were diverse and well informed, and they brought forward information, ideas and experiences which were quite valuable. I think that, for those who were not aware of this problem, the day was a useful exercise in encapsulating some of the issues.

I say `some' of the issues because there is a very real danger that we start to treat suicide as a kind of disease that is preventable—that we actually look at some ways of inoculating people or perhaps immunising them against suicide. There is a real danger that we see it as being something in isolation. In that context, I want to make some comments about some of the issues that are involved in youth suicide, and in suicide in general, so we are dealing with the person in a holistic way.

At the seminar and in other forums it has become clear that suicide seems to be a person's statement that their life has no further meaning; there is no further point. For one reason or another, an individual decides that there is no longer a meaningful place for them here on this earth, amongst the people that they have normally been amongst. How those decisions are made and in what context varies enormously, and there is a very great danger that, because we use the same word, we tend to group them as having similar reasons and similar backgrounds. The fact is that they do not.

If we look at, for example, sexuality amongst young males, particularly in remote and rural areas, we find that, as we discovered in our parliamentary inquiry into aspects of youth homelessness and from talking to some people in the gay and lesbian community, there is an enormous pressure there, particularly on young men who perhaps conclude that they may have a sexual preference which is not normal in their context and their environment and are therefore alienated. Many of those young men end up in cities and end up suiciding, one way or another.

We have to understand that, when a society goes through the kind of changes that we are going through in terms of family breakdowns, there may well be casualties. And the casualties may well be young people who no longer have either a place in the world or a family. In our report on youth homelessness tabled in the previous parliament, we pointed out that some 60 per cent of young people on youth homeless allowance came from single or blended families. In other words, almost two out of three people who were claiming that allowance were from a family that had broken down.

At the same time, we have been watching with great alarm the massive increase in abuse of young people. One can argue about whether we are getting more reporting and whether or not the actual incidence of abuse has changed a lot, because in past years child abuse was not reported in the same way and was not investigated. But the fact is that, since it has been reported and since it has been mandatory, the numbers are increasing every year in a way that is truly alarming. If there is an epidemic in our society, the epidemic is more likely to be child abuse than suicide. Looking at those young people who do suicide and those young people who are homeless, one finds that the incidence of abuse appears to be very high.

The fact that we have something like 30,000 confirmed cases of abuse of our young people per year should be a cause of enormous distress to us—as should be the fact that so many people who are committing abuse are not charged or in any way penalised for it. It is not simply paedophilia, currently in the public eye, but all abuse that is much worse. The effect of it in demeaning, demoralising and, in fact, eventually destroying so many young Australians must not be underestimated.

Suicide is not necessarily a self‐generated conclusion. In so many cases it is generated by what is done to one, and the effect of the loss of esteem, confidence and sense of self that is brought about by acts of abuse on young people is, to my mind, a vast and unrecognised dark side of our society. As I said, every year the figures come out and they increase year after year. I suppose that those of us who watch that and are concerned about that would recognise the difficulty of definition. We recognise all those complications, but the facts are inescapable: there is a major problem in our society with young people being treated as objects that are able to be abused.

In the report that we dealt with in 1995, after a very extensive range of inquiries around the country and submissions and a whole range of discussions, I was disturbed—and I still am disturbed—that so many parliamentarians were in fact blaming young people. The difficulty of determining homelessness and abuse is profound, but the risks are so great that most people working in the field tend to take the view that you give the first credibility to the young people themselves. All the evidence would indicate that in the vast majority of cases that is correct. I was therefore somewhat dismayed back in 1995 when members of the now government actually questioned that and actually made the claim in their minority report that they had reservations about the claims for homelessness. In fact they had the idea, which is still current, that our young people fabricate claims for the homelessness allowance.

The fact that we are getting 30,000 cases of abuse per year should be grounds enough for every one of us to overcompensate and to be, if you like, totally alert to it. But the fact is that two current ministers and a number of other present government members were, in the previous parliament, saying two things. They were saying, firstly, that they had reservations about the bona fides of claimants; and their second point was, effectively, compulsory mediation. In other words, we should make the young person and the parent, who may well be a step‐parent, engage in a process of mediation which would in fact expose the young person to having to confront the person that they were accusing or the person that in many cases was abusing. Of course, what that means is very simple: young people do not report.

The whole message there was that the parent was always right. That is still the message. They have translated from opposition into government and have kept the message running, and I think that should be of concern. So, for those people in the government now who are concerned about suicide, I would put it to you that it does not come about by accident; it does not happen as a one‐off thing. In so many cases, it is an end result of something else.

Another ingredient involved is the question of mental health—and, again, during that inquiry we were alarmed at the evidence brought forward of the incidence of mental health problems amongst our young. The fact is that about 50 per cent of all severe psychiatric illnesses are diagnosed by the age of 19 and the median age for half of our mental disorders is 16; yet, when you look at the expenditure on mental health, you will find that the vast bulk of it—something like 93 per cent of it—is on adults. In other words, we have a serious problem with the numbers of young people with mental health problems who are not being serviced, who are not getting the attention and support they need. Closely associated—and, in many cases, linked—with that are the problems of drug and alcohol abuse.

What I am trying to suggest is that suicide, particularly youth suicide, is often a matter of their total environment—of their background, of family disruption, of abuse, and eventually the question of identity, esteem and optimism. Abuse and family breakdowns often destroy the identity. Equally, they destroy the esteem. Optimism is another factor in the sense that other matters impact on that. Confidence in one's capacity to play a meaningful role, confidence in one's capacity to have a meaningful relationship, confidence to be a successful parent themselves, in so many young people is lacking. That comes back to the question of economics. Our young people, together with the majority of our older people, see governments and parliamentarians as being preoccupied with economics and not the community.

The famous Thatcher statement `There are no communities, just individuals' echoes very strongly in this situation. If you are the individual that she spoke of and you have been a victim of abuse or of family breakdown, if you are not that clever and not that well educated, then do you exist? The idea that you exist by yourself has been one of the most damaging and destructive elements in our sociological development this century. The fact is that youth suicide is in proportions which should alarm us. However, as I said at the start, we should not see it as a disease in isolation that we cannot prevent. We really must see it as part of something else. Unless we get to the real symptoms and treat them and address them, all the rest is rhetoric and posturing.

I encourage those in the government who have not read the report on youth homelessness to read it because what we uncovered in that report, as did Brian Burdekin, was a sickness in our society of serious proportions. The victims of that sickness were not the adults; they were the young. In many cases those young people survived, and some heroically.

I met a young woman who was 14½ and she had been a prostitute for a year, since she was 13½. I met another young woman who was a graduate of a university. She had left school at 14 and been a prostitute at 14, but she had come through all that and got educated and gained a degree. There were enormously heroic stories. I also met some people who I do not think are alive any more. I met a young man in a squat who is now dead, who suicided.

When one looks at that evidence there is not much point in coming to the end of the thing and saying, `How can we prevent youth suicide?' because the forces have been laid down in many cases five, 10 or 15 years before, and no-one gave a damn. Maybe they had told somebody but no‐one cared, or they were not believed. There were so many cases where young people were sent back to abusive households. There were so many cases where mothers had to choose between their daughters and their then husband or partner. There were so many cases where no-one seemed to give a damn, and the end result is we all get worried about youth suicide.

If we do not start worrying a lot sooner and believing these people a lot earlier and understanding them a lot better, we will see a lot more suicides, not fewer suicides. No amount of strategies in documenting, in isolating, in having help lines or anything else, will assist— because they are all treating the symptoms when we have to treat the cause. We have to get back to understanding what is happening to our young people at an earlier stage, not when they are teenagers. In many cases the causes arise when they are four or five or six or eight years of age.

The committee's report is of value to the parliament and the community. It is of even more value when it is linked with its previous report on youth homelessness. I would urge all parliamentarians to look much more closely at not just the issue of suicide but youth trauma, youth development and the family frameworks in which they grow up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Entsch, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking on this occasion about the summary report entitled Aspects of youth suicide . I intend to address the extraordinarily high representation that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians make in the national statistics. I do this not to downplay the human tragedy of non‐ATSI suicide but to highlight the difference between the ATSI and non‐ATSI experience of youth suicide, which should give some indication of how our best efforts might be better directed in combating suicide in an approach which will recognise the uniqueness of ATSI suicide and self‐harm.

SPEECH.PARA: An indictment of the seriousness of youth suicide is evident in one of the ATSI communities in my electorate which, sadly, currently holds the unfortunate reputation of having the largest number of youth suicides in the country and one of the largest in the world. Standing almost as a monument, and an ongoing reminder to the tragedy of the children in this community, is a tree known locally as the hanging tree which, to date, has provided a means to suicide for 20 young people in that community—a frightening statistic by anybody's reckoning.

The summary report Aspects of youth suicide points to factors such as age, family separation history, geographic isolation, unemployment, and drug and alcohol use. If these are important factors in increases in suicide amongst Australians, then it would seem that they would be more relevant to ATSI Australians, and I shall address these individually. Suicide rates amongst white Australians remain fairly constant at around 15 to 20 cases per 100,000 Australians from the age of 16 to 75‐plus. ATSI suicide, on the other hand, is a problem that is particularly a youth related one. Suicide rates amongst black Australians can be measured in significant numbers from an earlier age of 13. The number rises dramatically to nearly double that of non‐ATSI suicide by early adulthood. By mid‐adulthood, the rate drops by two-thirds and, surprisingly, further reduces to insignificant numbers by the age of 55.

BREAK.PARA: The trauma of divorce or parental separation is a factor in many youth suicides. I guess the official state sanction of family separation would surely have had a greatly increased result, one would imagine. The Bringing them home report demonstrated the dramatic effects that this had on the lives of those that the family separation policy touched. The ratio of urban to non‐urban ATSI Australians is roughly 70 to 30 whereas the reverse is the case for non‐ATSI Australians.

Those in remote and rural areas do not only suffer from a lack of the many crisis support systems available for those in urban areas but they also suffer, as all members of regional electorates know well, worse standards in terms of infrastructure and opportunity. ATSI unemployment stands at four times the national average, at about 40 per cent. According to leading experts on ATSI suicide in Australia and to the author of Aboriginal health and history, Professor Ernest Hunter, drug use and alcoholism appear to be the most significant immediate causes of suicide.

Professor Hunter heads an excellent team of academics with social and preventative medicine based in Cairns in my electorate. The work of this unit is well regarded nationally through its hands‐on approach with the larger ATSI population centres improving ATSI health outcomes. Professor Hunter claimed a significant victory recently for Far North Queensland to lead the way in research and training to solve chronic problems facing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health, when a $1.5 million funding allocation to establish a centre of excellence in ATSI health was awarded to a joint submission of the University of Queensland and the Queensland University of Technology, which will conduct much of its work through the social and preventative medicine units in Cairns.

According to Professor Hunter, increased vulnerability to suicide was first experienced by young Aboriginal males passing into and through adolescence in the late 1980s. As suicide is an end point—as are also increasing rates of alcohol abuse, self‐mutilation, child abuse and domestic violence—much can be learnt by exploring the background factors rather than seeking a cause in the immediate circumstances. We should look at the situation for Aboriginal Australians reaching maturity in the 1980s, which was shaped by the experience of those young adults who were having children through the 1970s.

This is a period of tumultuous change, with significant consequences for social roles within Aboriginal Australia. A generation who were young adults at the time of the Commonwealth referendum experienced entry into a cash economy, with unemployment and welfare dependence and increasing access to alcohol, following the legislation of its sale to Aboriginal Australians. Circumstances of continuing social disadvantage and binge drinking provided a context in which the impulsive, aggressive expression of tension resulted in escalating interpersonal violence. This proposition of increasing violence is supported by statistics showing an increase in suicide by violent means. Research by Harrison and Moller conducted in 1994 showed that 93 per cent of Aboriginal suicides resulted from hanging or firearms, compared with 43 per cent of non‐Aboriginal deaths, a comparison not shown in the Aspects of youth suicide summary report.

The Australian Institute of Suicide Research and Prevention report to the Commonwealth last year showed that those means are also the most lethal. Given the availability of means, with guns being readily available in remote areas and rural settings—and hanging being a matter of opportunity rather than means—and the connection with alcohol, the impulsivity is particularly important.

Research conducted by Professor Hunter and others for the National Drug and Alcohol Research Centre in Sydney revealed that impulses to self harm and suicide were widely experienced by ATSIC informants, with a moderate association to drinking status. However, acting on those impulses was strongly associated with alcohol, and it was the quantity consumed per drinking occasion rather than the frequency of consumption that predicted past self‐harmful or suicidal acts. Rather than being causal in an absolute sense, alcohol appears to enable the acting out of simmering impulses that may be otherwise better coped with.

Sadly, of a more sinister nature, an area of concern is the sexual abuse of children, a contributing factor no doubt to youth suicide. Unfortunately, this is very prolific in some ATSI communities. Reports that I have received in my office would certainly appear to confirm this. A recorded high incidence of sexually transmitted diseases, particularly in very young children, in some of the communities undoubtedly confirms this factor. I have had evidence received in my office of children as young as six and seven with very serious advanced forms of sexual disease. Clearly, this is a major factor with regard to the well‐being of that child. I feel that this is an area that really needs to be explored a lot more and to be dealt with very firmly and harshly if we have any way of being able to give those kids any sort of future.

Unfortunately, it is because it is of a very sensitive nature that the issue tends to be swept under the carpet. Unless it is addressed in a more open forum, along with the other contributing factors like substance abuse and unemployment, the issue of youth suicide will never ever be resolved.

Thirty years after the Commonwealth referendum, the tensions experienced by young adult Aborigines in relation to the wider society are probably greater than those experienced by their parents at a similar age. We are now at an historic point with the ability to accept these facts and seriously address them. The acceptance by the government of this report gives the opportunity for experts in the field to have a direct line of communication with the highest levels of the decision‐making process. With this prospect, I certainly commend the report to the House with two qualifications. Firstly, I would be greatly concerned should the priority 3 recommendation that an immediate review of current funding and redirection of some funds to a more appropriate and better targeted program lead to a reduction of the level of funding for ATSI suicide prevention, which currently stands at $1.058 million out of a $32 million budget.

Secondly, I support the recommendation of the report that a national advisory council be established to provide strategic advice to the minister and government on youth suicide prevention and related matters. But I would recommend that this council must contain an expert on ATSI suicide, given the uniqueness of the ATSI situation.

Youth suicide is certainly a blight on our society—a cancer, if you like—and it is clear that it crosses all cultural boundaries. Our youth are our future and it is essential that we as a society do all in our power to address this tragedy. I will, of course, continue to fully support all efforts and initiatives in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gambaro, Teresa, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to also address the topic which has become so significant. There are very few communities that have not come to grips with the devastation of youth suicide. The incidence of suicide has now reached most unacceptable levels, particularly in regional areas and particularly with respect to males.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the increase in the rate of suicide in cities should not be minimised. According to a recent publication from the Australian Institute for Suicide Research and Prevention, there are upwards of 2,500 deaths recorded as suicide each year. Queensland and Tasmania have the highest incidences of suicides. A report recently released by the Queensland government indeed confirms this very sad fact.

However, even more disturbing is that for every successful suicide there are up to 300 female and 50 male unsuccessful attempts. In my own electorate of Petrie, as indeed in Australia, there are families who have known the pain and suffering of having someone close to them commit suicide. Recently, I hosted a breakfast in Margate, which Professor Baume and the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) convened. Over 100 people attended this breakfast. It was particularly sad at the end of the breakfast when I was speaking to a number of people who had been touched by this particular problem. A mother in tears approached me. She was absolutely devastated by the death of her son 12 months previously. She was still in a period of denial and did not understand why he had taken his life. But she felt reassured by coming along to the breakfast and she thanked me enormously for organising the breakfast. It gave her great comfort and reassurance that there was nothing that she could have done and no way that she could have predicted that he would take his life. I was able to then put her in touch with a support group of parents who are able to meet on a regular basis and discuss the issues of youth suicide.

The most tragic thing is that the people who are left behind are the ones that suffer for many years afterwards not knowing if there was something that they somehow could have done to prevent their young ones taking their lives. It is the not knowing that haunts them for the rest of their lives. It is important to emphasise that this touches everyone from family to friends. Quite often, the friends that are left in their wake and their family are the ones that really do need the help the most.

But it is an issue that does affect the lives of families, not only in the Redcliffe areas I have mentioned, in Deception Bay, but throughout Australia. We cannot ignore it as a community and we cannot really take it very lightly. We have a responsibility as a community not to trivialise this or ignore it, because it has very great social ramifications.

It is an issue that we see quite a lot. We see it in the media, in programs like 60 Minutes, and in publications. We even have the misfortune now to see it on the Internet. On one occasion, I heard Professor Baume speak of the role of the Internet and what young people use it for these days. They use it as a forum to communicate with each other on suitable and appropriate measures of suicide and they actually give each other tips on the most effective ways to commit suicide. It is disturbing to see that. There are thousands of hit sites on the Internet that deal with this. It is quite a blight on our society that the Internet is being used by young people to communicate these things.

As with any tragic death, the ramifications of suicide are very widespread but, unlike other tragic deaths, suicide brings with it great sadness, disbelief and guilt. As I mentioned, family and friends are the ones who find it very hard to understand. Like ripples in a pond, these deaths, by their very nature, cannot fail to affect everyone in the community. One thing I have noticed is that, if there are cases of suicide in families, it tends to be an intergenerational thing. There are certainly issues that never get resolved in the first place. It gets buried away under the carpet or in the cupboard. People do not speak about it, and intergenerational suicide is a very common thing.

We should really look at it very closely. We should be tireless in our efforts to find solutions because there is such despair and hopelessness among our young people. The member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) highlighted some terrible cases that he has come across. He touched me deeply when he spoke about the young women who had been to see him and the terrible cases of suicide. But young people can overcome some of these things. He spoke of some very positive instances where young women were prostitutes and were contemplating suicide but they were able to rebuild their lives and attend university and look forward to the future. He was right that we need to emphasise the youth aspects of it—the trauma and youth development—and I think that is very important to acknowledge.

I have spoken on this topic on many occasions and today I would like to acknowledge the efforts of the House, particularly the previous chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs in producing the report Aspects of youth suicide. The report followed a very successful seminar that was held here earlier this year. I was not a member of the committee but I did gain quite a lot from attending on that particular day. The speakers were top rate and, as I mentioned, I have since had contact with one of the speakers, Associate Professor Pierre Baume. He has made a number of contributions in this area. It is an area that he has studied for a number of years. His extensive research has tended to emphasise the sociological factors that contribute to youth suicide. He believes that these can be divided into categories: the global aspects and the personal aspects. He mentioned a number of things, and a number of speakers have highlighted them—for instance, the high divorce rate. One cannot underestimate the effect of divorce. It is a devastating thing. What is more devastating, when people do split up, is that children sometimes feel that they are the direct cause of it. It is never talked through with young children, and it is not explained that they are not really the central issue in a divorce.

Other areas were high youth and high female unemployment. Alcohol consumption, as the member for Leichhardt (Mr Entsch) mentioned, is clearly a big problem. A number of speakers have raised the issue of unwanted pregnancies and the devastation this can have on people's lives not just in the immediate present but also well into the future. There is a trend these days not to attend church and not to be community or religion focused. One cannot underestimate the importance of those factors—when people have no-one to talk to—and having community support.

There are some other facts that I would like to highlight, that come up frequently. The member for Leichhardt mentioned the rate of Aboriginal deaths by suicide. It is an area of grave concern. It is four times the rate of non-Aboriginals in Queensland. As I mentioned, for every suicide, there are a number of suicides that are attempted—and these are 100 times greater.

There is also the fact that there is a larger number of men who commit suicide than females. Blood alcohol levels and alcohol addictions clearly have a strong correlation with suicidal behaviour, particularly when you talk about binge drinking, which tends to occur mainly in summer. That was something that was highlighted at the recent breakfast that I hosted. These particular bouts of binge drinking occur in summer, and the rates of suicide are higher in summer.

Professor Baume mentioned that we needed to put more preventive measures in place. But then he highlighted that we need to be particularly concerned—and he quoted studies that go back 30 or so years—because sometimes if you do put in too many prevention measures, or not the right prevention measures, suicide rates actually go up in schools where they have had prevention measures. He emphasised that there was a greater need to put these measures in place when people reach young adulthood, rather than at schools. That was quite an interesting revelation. I was quite amazed when he made that particular revelation.

The main problems are definitely in the relationship area. I feel that young men do not mature as quickly as young women. Most of the problems are on a very personal level and they compound the situation. Things like the loss or death of a family friend, as I have mentioned, and break‐up of relationships clearly come into the equation, particularly with young males when they are not able to deal with the sense of rejection and loss. We need to spend a lot more money on relationship counselling and dealing with those sorts of issues as well because they are clearly a problem when people are not able to deal with the break‐up of a relationship or with grief issues.

The importance of these factors is seen in the results of a youth forum in my area, in Redcliffe. Those forums will be continuing. Whilst forums like these are very important to identify problems and suggest solutions, it is important that all levels in the community combine and cooperate to follow through in working out strategies and implementing programs to help realise these solutions.

The federal government has taken some steps, and they are to be commended, particularly in respect to the youth suicide issue. Upwards of $31 million is being spent on the national youth suicide prevention strategy, and they are very real and positive steps. Also, there is a provision of $6 million to states and territories to improve access in rural and remote areas to counselling; $6 million is being committed to Lifeline and Kids Helpline; and $3 million is being provided for programs for parents.

And let's not underestimate the benefit of parents. We all take an individual responsibility when we have children to ensure that they are brought up in the correct manner as far as their physical needs are concerned and their schooling. But psychological nurturing and self‐esteem are just as important. I know that negativity can be one of the greatest downfalls of any young person. We do need to nurture and look after our young people.

All the research that I have seen on overseas countries and the incidence of suicide—and, clearly, Australia and New Zealand seem to have the highest rates in the industrialised world—point to the factor of cultural and family influence. It is no coincidence when you see European countries with lower levels of youth suicide. One has to detect from that: is the family environment such that it does not encourage suicide? What is being done culturally in these countries that prevents suicide? Is it a stronger family situation? Is it the role of the extended family? We cannot underestimate how important family influences and upbringing are in this particular issue.
The previous Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) best summed it up in June this year, when she launched the national youth suicide program, when she said:
When so many of our young people are dying by their own hand through despair, desperation, frustration, or loneliness, it is a problem that demands national attention and national action.
The recommendations of the committee's report are that developments in the effective service delivery of these programs and strategies will be based on positive and up‐to‐date information.

The integration of suicide research is needed to ensure that grants are used effectively. There has to be some sort of consistency and accuracy in data collection in Australia. It is very disturbing when you see that there is no national database for suicide, and that the statistics are very sketchily collected and are very ad hoc. We really need to look at focusing on that. If we know the extent of the problem that we are dealing with, we can deal with it much more effectively. I emphasise the need for greater research and figures in this area.

The federal government has shown that it is prepared to support and assist those who are at risk and are classified as prime candidates for youth suicide. The fact that the committee advocates the constant review of Australia's suicide strategy emphasises the fact that the strategies and funding policies need to be continually monitored, and updated if necessary.

I think that it is important that the information be provided, that it is designed to assist families and those at risk, and that it needs to be as readily and widely available as possible. Doctors, teachers, counsellors, representatives at all levels of government, and particularly young people, should have access not only to this relevant information but also to the contact details. This is particularly important for families in crisis.

The solution to youth suicide is very complex and very sensitive and this government has made, and will make, a significant effort to listen to and address the needs of that part of our community which right at this very minute is crying out in loneliness and desperation. I think that the most important step, the next step—prevention—is going to be very much harder, and we really do need to emphasise it.
Debate (on motion by Mr Anthony) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 26 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to question No. 1376 (Hansard 13 May 1997, page 3411), is he arranging for a risk analysis to be undertaken in the Government's consideration of Airservices Australia's report on the long term operating plan for Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport and associated airspace.

(2) If so, (a) who is undertaking the analysis and (b) will he refer to that person or organisation the concerns voiced by air traffic controllers and pilots regarding the current method of operation of the airport.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. I am advised by Airservices Australia that it is preparing a comprehensive Safety Case in accordance with my direction on the implementation of the Long Term Operating Plan for Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport.

(2) Airservices Australia has engaged Praxis Critical Systems Limited to carry out an independent review of safety issues. The consultant will be free to meet with Air Traffic Controllers and industry users during the audit process.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 25 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will additional homes be insulated against aircraft noise in the electoral division of Barton following his adoption of the long term operating plan for Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport; if so, what homes.
(2) What criteria have been used by the Government to assess homes to be eligible for insulation.

(3) Do the criteria involve Australian Noise Exposure Forecast (ANEF) contours; if so, do those contours take into account higher altitude areas which, although a distance away from the end of the east‐west runway, may be exposed to severe aircraft noise as a result of the shorter distance between their homes and the overflying aircraft.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. An additional 556 homes in the Barton electorate have been invited to participate in the Sydney Airport Noise Insulation Program.

(2) Eligibility for aircraft noise insulation assistance under the Sydney Airport Noise Insulation Program is based on noise exposure as calculated under the Australian Noise Exposure Forecast system. Residential properties within the 30 Australian Noise Exposure Forecast contour are eligible for insulation assistance.

It is not yet possible to determine a reliable Australian Noise Exposure Forecast which reflects the Long Term Operating Plan arrangements. Consequently, Australian Noise Exposure Concepts (ANECs) have been produced based on the best information currently available. These have been used to re‐prioritise the noise insulation program on an interim basis.

(3) See answer to Question 2. Airservices Australia, which is the organisation within Australia responsible for vetting the technical accuracy of noise exposure forecasts, advises that topography is not taken into account in determining the ANEC's.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 25 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a recent ram‐raid robbery at the International Terminal at Sydney (Kingsford‐Smith) Airport.
(2) Will he review the adequacy of the security at the airport in light of the incident.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) As the honourable member has noted, the purpose of the ram‐raid was theft; in this case goods were stolen from one of the duty free shops in the airport terminal at a time the terminal was not in operation.

Security arrangements for protection of shops is the responsibility of the Federal Airports Corporation and retailer. The protection arrangements can be compared with the protection for shops in normal shopping centres.

Special security arrangements are, however, in place to protect the public during times when the terminal is operational. These arrangements include supplementing community policing by patrols of armed officers of the Australian Protective Service.

The out of hours robbery does not throw into question the arrangements for the protection of aviation operations and public safety. The arrangements would, of course, be reviewed if the current level of threat changes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 25 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has research been undertaken as to the size of the market for illegal drugs in Australia in terms of the annual monetary value of the trade; if so, what have been the findings of the studies.
(2) Have studies been undertaken as to the extent to which the market in illegal drugs has been funded by criminal activity.

(3) Has his attention been drawn to trials undertaken in Switzerland and The Netherlands in an endeavour to reduce the size of the market for illegal drugs in those countries; if so, is the Minister able to say (a) what has been the nature of those trials and (b) have those trials had success in reducing the extent of the market in illegal drugs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that as far as it is possible to ascertain there have been no national studies conducted into the size of the market for illegal drugs.
(2) I am advised that as far as it is possible to ascertain there have been no national studies conducted into the extent to which the market in illegal drugs has been funded by criminal activity.

(3) I am aware of the trial conducted in the last two or three years in Switzerland, although I am advised that the focus of this trial is the gathering of experimental and research data associated with the treatment of heroin dependent persons with diacetylmorphine (pharmaceutical heroin) and other opiates. As far as can be ascertained, the similar trial in the Netherlands, while planned and recently announced in the media, has not yet commenced. (a) The nature of these trials is as described above. (b) It is not known whether the trial in Switzerland has been successful in reducing the extent of the market in illegal drugs.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Noise Monitoring Devices

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 26 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Have noise monitoring devices been relocated as a result of the adoption of the Long Term Operating Plan for Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport; if so, to where have they been relocated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No. The location of the 12 permanent noise monitoring terminals will be reviewed following the introduction of the new flight paths under the Plan in early December 1997.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 27 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to his answer to a question without notice (Hansard , page 6801) 26 August 1997, (a) what mineral exports will develop as a result of the completion of the Darwin to Alice Springs railway, (b) where are the minerals located and (c) who has the rights to those minerals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In his answer on 26 August 1997, the former Minister for Transport and Regional Development quoted from a 1993 report by Morrison Knudsen which states that the Alice Springs‐Darwin railway project would stimulate mineral exports from the north.

I am advised that this was a general observation and it would not be appropriate or sensible to try to specify which of the particular mineral deposits which might be found would benefit from the line or who might own the rights to these deposits. The key point is, however, that given the ability of rail to move high volume mineral traffic much more cheaply and efficiently than road, the completion of this important link to the port of Darwin is likely to benefit the exploitation of any large mineral deposits discovered in localities that the line can serve.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 28 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Do Qantas and Ansett code‐share with other airlines on international routes; if so, (a) which routes, (b) which other airlines are involved and (c) what checks are in place to ensure that the standard of airworthiness of planes and competence of the crews is equivalent to those operated directly by Qantas and Ansett.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Both Qantas and Ansett have extensive code‐share arrangements with numerous airlines.

Qantas code‐shares on flights to and from Austria, Canada, Fiji, Japan, Korea, the Netherlands, New Caledonia, Papua New Guinea, the Solomon Islands, Vanuatu and the United States. Qantas has code‐share arrangements with British Airways, Canadian Airlines International, Air Pacific, Japan Airlines, Asiana Airlines, Martinair, Air Caledonie, Air Niugini, Solomon Airlines, Air Vanuatu, American Airlines, USAir Inc and Federal Express.
Ansett code‐shares on flights to and from Korea, Malaysia, New Zealand and Taiwan on flights operated by Korean Air, Malaysia Airlines, Air New Zealand and Eva Air.

Any airline operating to Australia on a regular basis is required to obtain an Australian foreign aircraft Air Operator's Certificate from the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA). Occasional flights require individual clearance from CASA. Airlines who do not operate into Australia but are code‐sharing partners of Qantas and Ansett are the responsibility of the safety regulatory authority of the country of the aircraft's registration. They may also be subject to inspection by the regulatory authorities of the countries they transit through.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 1 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to her answer to question No. 1813 (Hansard , 28 August 1997, page 7165), is she satisfied with the situation where 43 of the 132 redress es of grievance being investigated or awaiting investigation on behalf of a Chief of Service or the Chief of the Defence Force have been under consideration for over 9 months; if not, what processes has she undertaken to expedite decision making.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bishop, Bronwyn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There are many reasons why the resolution of individual redresses of grievance which have been referred to the Chiefs of Service or the Chief of the Defence Force or their delegates may be delayed.

The prioritising of complaints is done on a daily basis. In this regard, some complaints are more urgent than others. For example, cases which involve serious matters, or which are time‐critical involving executive action such as posting or discharge, are normally allocated the highest priority. Delays can occur when complaints are afforded a low priority.

Delays can also occur in complex cases, where investigations may become lengthy and involved. In addition, in some cases, complainants delay their responses to requests for additional information which would enable their complaint to be progressed. Finally, some members are slow in providing advice as to whether they are satisfied with decisions made by their Chief of Service, or if they wish their complaint to be further considered by the Chief of the Defence Force. In a recent case, two years elapsed before an officer decided that he wished his complaint to be referred to the Chief of the Defence Force.

In order to determine the reasons for the various delays in finalising individual applications for redress of grievance, a physical search of all redress of grievance files would be necessary. I am not prepared to commit further resources for this task.

Some steps have been taken to improve the current processes for handling ADF members' redresses of grievance. On 1 July 1997, a combined Complaint Resolution Agency was created in the Defence Personnel Executive. A focus of the new Agency will be to establish, to the greatest extent possible, common procedures for the handling of complaints and to encourage the resolution of complaints at the lowest level. The integration and rationalisation of Service complaint management functions should lead to the more efficient handling of ADF members' complaints.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 1 September 1997:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Has the Government changed the requirements for quality assurance for use in Government tenders; if so, (a) what are the new provisions and (b) when will quality assurance be required for Government supplies.
(2) Has progress been made in the use of electronic commerce for Government purchasing contracts; if so, what.
(3) Who is entitled to use the Transigo system and at what cost.
(4) Are provisions being made to include State government purchasing units and local governments in the system; if so, what.
(5) What has been the cost to the Government of establishing the Transigo system.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There has been no change to the Commonwealth Government's requirements for quality assurance in Government tenders. The policy has always been to consider the need for quality assurance on a case by case basis, taking into account the risks associated with the provision and use of those purchases. This is clearly stated in the recently released Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines.

(2) Yes. In November 1996 the Commonwealth and Telstra entered into a Deed of Agreement under which Telstra would establish and operate a Commonwealth Electronic Commerce Service (CECS). CECS, now known as `Transigo', was to be funded on a user‐pays basis and implemented in a series of releases, offering progressively expanded functionality.
The first release of Transigo was made available in March 1997, with additional functionality added in a number of sub‐releases since then.
Commonwealth buyers use Transigo to advertise bidding opportunities and report their purchasing, while suppliers are able to access this information.
Telstra has announced further developments of Transigo. An electronic trading document service will be available by December 1997 and an electronic payment service by March 1998.

(3) Transigo is an Internet‐based service. It has a free‐to‐air component which provides basic access to summary information about Commonwealth business opportunities and contracts and standing offers arranged by the Commonwealth.

Buyers and suppliers can also subscribe to Transigo for a basic annual subscription cost of $348 per user. This currently allows buyers to publish opportunities on Transigo and suppliers to download tender documentation and advertise their goods and services, with additional functionality to be provided in future releases.
Additional services are available for the following fees:
. Automated tender matching and notification: $240 p.a.
. Data storage in excess of 5 Mb: $0.20 per Mb per day
. Manual upload of information by Transigo Support Centre: $10 per notice
. Bid request line: download and postal distribution of tender documents by the Transigo Support Centre: $15 per item.

(4) The impetus behind Transigo originated with the Commonwealth, and other tiers of government are being encouraged to use Transigo to conduct procurement. It is intended that Transigo will also become a medium for business‐to‐business transactions.
Transigo provides links to state government Internet sites and information about their procurement policies and practices.

(5) The development and implementation of Transigo is being undertaken by Telstra following an extensive tendering process. The terms of the contractual arrangements between the Commonwealth and Telstra are such that there are no payments by the Commonwealth to Telstra to establish the service. The project is being funded on a user‐pays basis through subscriptions to Transigo by buyers and suppliers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: West, Andrea, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 24 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the timetable for fully introducing electronic commerce for government purchasing.
(2) What will be the subscription cost for small businesses to access the system.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable Member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In July 1996 this Government approved a strategy for implementing electronic commerce by the Commonwealth. Under this strategy, Departments would use a Commonwealth Electronic Commerce Service (CECS) to trade electronically with their suppliers.
In November 1996 the Commonwealth and Telstra entered into a Deed of Agreement under which Telstra would establish and operate CECS, to be known as `Transigo', on a user-pays basis.

The first release of Transigo was made available in March 1997, with additional functionality added in a number of sub-releases since then. Government agencies are obliged to use Transigo from 1 July 1997 to advertise publicly available bidding opportunities and notify all purchases of $2000 or more and standing offers arranged. The electronic version of the Commonwealth Purchasing and Disposals Gazette has been available on Transigo since 28 July 1997.
Telstra has recently announced further development of Transigo, with an electronic trading document service to be available by December 1997 and an electronic payment service by March 1998.
Future releases of Transigo will provide additional functionality, in line with latest developments in technology and procurement practice.

(2) Anyone can access the free-to-air component of Transigo through any Internet Service Provider. This provides basic access to summary information about Commonwealth business opportunities and contracts and standing offers arranged by the Commonwealth.

Buyers and suppliers can also subscribe to Transigo for a basic annual subscription cost of $348 per user. This allows buyers to publish opportunities on Transigo and suppliers to download tender documentation and advertise their goods and services. Future functionality will be included as part of the subscription at no additional cost.
Additional services are available for the following fees:
• Automated tender matching and notification: $240 p.a.
• Data storage in excess of 5 Mb: $0.20 per Mb per day.
• Manual upload of information by the Transigo Support Centre: $10 per notice.
• Bid request line: download and postal distribution of tender documents by the Transigo Support Centre: $ 15 per item.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Defence: Middle Head Land

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: Is there an agreement between the Commonwealth and the State of New South Wales entered into in 1979 in relation to Defence Department land at Middle Head in order for the land being incorporated into the Sydney Harbour National Park as it becomes surplus to Defence requirements; if so, will the Government honour the agreement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McLachlan, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In 1979, the Commonwealth and the New South Wales Governments reached agreement (the Sydney Harbour Foreshores Agreement) on the exchange of land, which included the Commonwealth transferring land to form the Sydney Harbour National Park. The agreement provided for a pooling arrangement, based on transactions at agreed prices, and was to continue until balance, or near balance, was reached and, failing that, for a ten year period.

During 1989, the Commonwealth indicated to the State that it did not wish to renegotiate the agreement because the original purpose had been achieved. The Commonwealth also stated its willingness to proceed with the transfer of land still outstanding, subject to negotiation on price. This included 6.5 hectares of Defence land at Middle Head.
When the 6.5 hectares of land at Middle Head is no longer required for Defence purposes, it will be transferred to the State in accordance with the terms of the original agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 30 September 1997:

(2) How many persons are employed at each establishment identified in part (1).
(3) Is action being taken by the Minister's Department to stop the instrumentalities, agencies or installations from polluting the Georges River; if so, what.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McLachlan, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The following Defence installations border on, or are close to, the Georges River:

(a) Holsworthy Training Area; (b) School of Military Engineering which includes a nearby training area known as `Camp Sapper'; (c) Sydney West Office of the Defence Corporate Support Organisation; (d) old Holsworthy Sewage Treatment Plant; (e) East Hills Barracks; (f) Lamia Barracks; (g) Defence National Storage and Distribution Centre; (h) Sydney West Regional Estate Centre; and (i) Holsworthy Barracks.
In addition to these installations, the Department of Defence also leases a small area of land, which is adjacent to the Georges River, to the Boy Scouts Association of NSW.

With respect to the disposal of waste, chemicals, debris or effluent, each Defence installation collects stormwater which eventually flows into the Georges River; however, only the old Holsworthy Sewage Treatment Plant uses the river for the disposal of effluent and this will cease in the near future pending the augmentation of the western Sydney sewage treatment scheme.
(2) (a) Holsworthy Training Area—8

(b) School of Military Engineering—282; (c) Sydney West Office of the Defence Corporate Support Organisation—237; (d) old Holsworthy Sewage Treatment Plant—4; (e) East Hills Barracks—19; (f) Lamia Barracks—54; (g) Defence National Storage and Distribution Centre—950; (h) Sydney West Regional Estate Centre—25; (i) Holsworthy Barracks—2100.

(3) Yes. This action includes: (a) upgrading sewage reticulation and trade waste facilities prior to decommissioning the old Holsworthy Sewage Treatment Plant and the consequential diversion of sewage into Sydney Water's western sewage treatment scheme; (b) integrating stormwater systems; (c) improving procedures in relation to accidental spills; (d) developing environmental management plans; and (e) auditing existing waste disposal practices.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Transport and Regional Development: Georges River

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 1 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister's Department have agencies, instrumentalities or installations bordering on the Georges River, NSW; if so, do they use the river for disposal of waste, chemical, debris or effluent.
(2) How many persons are employed at each establishment identified in part (1).
(3) Is action being taken by the Minister's Department to stop the instrumentalities or installations from polluting the Georges River, if so, what.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes; Bankstown Airport, one of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) airports, is near the Georges River. Bankstown does not use the Georges River to dispose of waste, chemicals, debris or effluent.
(2) Approximately 2800 people in various businesses across the airport.

(3) Bankstown Airport has an Environmental Management Plan (EMP) in place covering environmental interaction and potential impact of the airport on the environment. In general, the scope of the EMP covers these activities occurring within the Airport boundaries other than those associated with aircraft movements and operations. The Georges River, and its close proximity to the airport is addressed within the EMP, and steps have been taken to ensure that aviation activities do not have an environmental impact upon the Georges River.

Under the EMP, tenants are audited every two years to determine any impact they may have on the local environment, storm water discharges and ground water are regularly monitored, FAC staff are trained on environmental issues annually and pollution absorbent booms have been installed at all stormwater outlets in order to contain any contaminants that may accidentally enter the stormwater system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 2 October 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government commissioned studies, or sought advice, on the economic cost to Australia's rural industries if greenhouse climate change was to cause global surface temperatures to increase by 2 degrees C; if so, (a) what were the results and (b) will they be published.
(2) If work has not been commissioned, nor advice sought, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Listed below are research projects commissioned by the Department of the Environment which bear on the economic impact of a 2 degree C rise in temperature from climate change on Australia's rural industries.

The projects include impacts associated with a specific 2 degree C rise in temperature. The estimated costs from the impacts of climate change are, however, generally calculated for a range of temperatures (e.g. with temperature increases from 0.5-2.0 degree C or from 1.0-5.0 degree C).
Projects are still in progress, but it is expected that results of each project will be published in due course.
a. Potential impact of defoliating insects in rural tree decline under climate change.
b. State of the Science Assessment: Impact of Global Change on Arthropod Pests, Weeds and Diseases of Australian Terrestrial Ecosystems.
Some preliminary information on this project is available at http://www.modeling.ctpm.uq.edu.au/ dest_public/ destmain htm
c. Land Use in Northern Australia: Impacts of market, policy and climate change.
d. Economic and social consequences of a climate change induced reduction in snow cover in the Victorian Alps

In addition, the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation, which is largely funded by government, is currently supporting the following projects which also bear on the economic impact of climate change on Australia's rural industries
e. The impacts of global warming on world and Australian agriculture
f. Predicting the impact of climate change on plant diseases of economic significance to Australia
g. Impact of a climate change on pests and pest management strategies
h. Use of a simulation model to predict future distributions of exotic woody weeds under climate change.
(2) Not applicable.
